This is a methodological tutorial/review of intersubject correlation rather than an original fMRI study reporting data from healthy adult participants performing a social task; abstract lacks participant/task/whole-brain results and fits exclusion for reviews/meta-analyses.

The study investigates face-processing networks in people with temporal lobe epilepsy (a neurological disorder), so participants are not healthy adults. This meets the exclusion criterion for studies reporting results among participants with neurological disorders; thus excluded.

fMRI study investigating neural activity during reflection of one’s own and a friend’s attributes (social cognition) in healthy adult males; reports whole-brain activations and connectivity across several regions. No indication of patient sample or ROI-only analysis. Age range not specified but participants described as adults—include for full-text confirmation.

Participants were patients diagnosed with schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder (clinical population). Review excludes studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders; thus the study is not eligible despite using fMRI and a social (ToM) task with whole-brain analyses.

fMRI study of live reciprocal social interaction (human-human vs human-robot) with n=21 healthy participants and contrasts reporting increased activation in TPJ, hypothalamus, and amygdala, indicating whole-brain results. No psychiatric/neurological disorders reported. Age range not specified in abstract—confirm in full text.

Study examines individuals with schizophrenia; exclusion criterion prohibits studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders. Abstract does not indicate healthy adult sample; therefore excluded.

Parametric fMRI study where participants evaluated political belief statements — a social cognition task. Abstract reports whole-brain activation patterns (mPFC, TPJ, DLPFC, ventral striatum, PCC). No ROI-only analyses, patient populations, or review. Participant age/health not specified; include for full-text verification.

Abstract describes an fMRI study (N=178) examining neural networks of empathy and mentalizing during social processing in (presumably) healthy adults; no indication of clinical sample or that only ROI analyses were used. The abstract lacks explicit ages and whole-brain reporting, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.
Participants are older adults (mean age 79), outside the required 18–60 age range. Although the study used fMRI of empathy, the age criterion alone excludes it from this review.

Study focuses on neural connectivity in Autism Spectrum Disorder (clinical population) rather than healthy adults, and describes functional connectivity of networks (likely resting-state) rather than fMRI during a social-related task. Thus it does not meet the healthy-participant and task-based inclusion criteria.

fMRI study where participants encoded facts about unfamiliar people (a social-related task). No indication of clinical populations (presumed healthy adults). Abstract reports conjunction analyses and effects in other brain regions, implying whole-brain results rather than ROI-only reporting. Include for full-text review to confirm age range and analytic details.

The abstract describes a narrative review of fMRI literature and a heuristic model in autism rather than an original fMRI study in healthy adults. It focuses on autism (clinical population) and is a review article—meeting exclusion criteria for reviews and studies of clinical participants; no primary whole-brain fMRI results in healthy 18–60 participants are reported.

fMRI study in healthy participants examining spontaneous imitation—a social process. Reports cortical areas with positive correlations and functional connectivity (whole-brain style reporting). Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility (age 18–60) and whole-brain analysis details.

Participants are children with pediatric stroke (neurological disorder), not healthy adults; study uses resting-state connectivity rather than task-based fMRI during a social-related task. Thus it does not meet inclusion criteria (healthy adults, task fMRI).

fMRI study of a social interaction task (human–human competition requiring Theory of Mind), reports whole-brain activations across multiple regions, and participants described as healthy. Abstract does not report participant ages (18–60 unclear). No exclusion criteria clearly met; include for full-text review to confirm age range and methods.

fMRI study of attractiveness comparisons (social processing) in human participants; not a review and no patient population reported. Age range and explicit whole-brain vs ROI analyses are not specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Study includes and reports results from participants with borderline personality disorder (psychiatric disorder). Exclusion criterion excludes studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders, so the study should be excluded despite using fMRI social tasks with healthy controls.

fMRI study in healthy human participants performing an animacy-perception task, which is a form of social-related processing; authors report whole-brain analyses. Age/health not explicitly stated in abstract — include for full-text screening to confirm participant demographics and eligibility.

fMRI study investigating social preference learning (participants viewed others’ choices), a social cognitive task in healthy adults; not a review and no indication it’s ROI-only or clinical. Abstract implies whole-brain activation (reports activity in brain areas). Some details (exact ages, explicit statement of whole-brain analysis) are not provided, so include for full-text review.
Participants are non-human (dogs). The review requires fMRI studies in healthy human adults (18–60); this study involves animals and therefore does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract refers specifically to individuals with schizophrenia and people with depression, indicating the study reports results from psychiatric patient groups. This violates the exclusion criterion disallowing studies reporting participants with psychiatric disorders. The abstract lacks evidence that the sample consists solely of healthy adults.

Abstract focuses on ERP (event-related potentials) and theory of emotion development/plasticity rather than reporting an fMRI study. No indication of an fMRI scan during a social task, no participant details, and appears to be a review/theoretical paper. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

Includes participants with schizophrenia (psychiatric disorder). Exclusion criteria disallow studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric/neurological disorders. Presence of a patient group in the study therefore warrants exclusion despite inclusion of healthy controls.

Study used fMRI during a Cyberball social exclusion task (meets social-related task). Participants appear to be healthy adults with no psychiatric/neurological sample reported. The abstract does not specify age range or explicitly state whole-brain analyses. Include for full-text review to confirm age eligibility and that whole-brain (not ROI-only) results were reported.

The study reports results from participants with a psychiatric disorder (women in recovery from anorexia nervosa) rather than only healthy adults. Because it includes and reports findings for a clinical group, it meets exclusion criteria.

Abstract reports event-related fMRI of a social resource-conflict task with human partners and appears to use whole-brain analysis, but does not specify participant ages (18–60) or explicitly state whole-brain reporting. Insufficient detail to confirm all inclusion criteria; include for full-text review.
Participants are infants (3–7 months), not healthy adults 18–60. The study therefore does not meet the age criterion for inclusion in the review.

fMRI study investigating neural response to social exclusion (a social task) in 21 healthy volunteers; reports whole-brain findings (dorsal ACC and middle frontal gyrus). Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participants meet 18–60 criterion and to verify full-brain analytic approach.

fMRI study where participants read social vs non-social literary passages and social-cognitive performance was measured; reports neural subnetworks (whole-brain patterns) and no indication of ROI-only analyses or clinical populations. Age range not specified but participants appear to be healthy adults; include for full-text to confirm demographics and whole-brain reporting.

fMRI study where participants performed a social interaction discrimination task; includes a healthy adult group (ages 20–41) and reports whole-brain activation patterns rather than ROI-only results. Include for full-text review to extract adult-specific whole-brain data.

Study reports fMRI during a social cognition/mentalizing task in healthy adults and addresses review objective. Abstract confirms healthy participants and task-related brain responses. However, it does not specify participant ages (18-60) nor explicitly state whole-brain results, so insufficient detail to confirm all inclusion criteria; include for full-text review.

Abstract describes fMRI in pre- and post-treatment depression — participants are individuals with a psychiatric disorder (depression), not healthy adults. This directly meets an exclusion criterion (studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders).

fMRI study where healthy adult participants (n=35) performed a social-related task (recall of relationship episodes). Abstract reports whole-brain activation across multiple regions (memory, self, affective areas). Not an ROI-only analysis, not a review, and participants are healthy. Satisfies inclusion criteria.

Participants are high-functioning youth with autism spectrum disorder (clinical population) and typically-developing youth—not healthy adults age 18–60. Study therefore does not meet the criterion of healthy adult participants and includes a psychiatric/neurological disorder group, so it should be excluded.

fMRI study of social-related processing (self-, mother-referential tasks and a social attribution/theory-of-mind task) with reported whole-brain group and conjunction analyses. No evidence of clinical populations or ROI-only reporting. Participant ages not specified, so include for full-text review to confirm 18–60 and health status.

fMRI study where healthy participants performed an emotion-related task (tracing emotion in vocalizations/music), reporting activation across multiple whole-brain regions (e.g., temporal cortex, medial frontal, ACC). No indication of ROI-only analyses or clinical samples. Age range not specified in abstract; include for full-text review to confirm ages and whole-brain reporting.

Study includes participants with first-episode schizophrenia (psychiatric disorder). Inclusion requires healthy participants; abstracts reporting results among psychiatric populations meet exclusion criteria. Although controls were included and task is social fMRI, presence of patient group warrants exclusion based on abstract alone.

fMRI study examining perception of social interactions in presumably healthy adult participants using point-light figures and moving shapes. Abstract does not specify participant ages or clearly state whole-brain results (some language suggests ROI/localization), so insufficient to determine inclusion; include for full-text review to confirm whole-brain analysis and age range.

This appears to be a review/perspective describing fMRI methods and discussing findings (including developmental/child-focused topics), not a primary fMRI study reporting whole-brain results in healthy adults 18–60; participant/task details are insufficient.

fMRI experiment with participants performing mentalising (social cognition) tasks; abstract reports recruitment of multiple brain regions (insula, posterior STS, temporal pole, cerebellum), implying whole-brain results. No indication of clinical/sample with disorders or ROI-only analyses. Age range not specified—confirm in full text.

fMRI study in healthy adults (n=15) performing a social task (viewing and rating social interactions), meeting the review objective. Abstract does not report participant ages or specify whether results are whole‑brain versus ROI analyses, so insufficient information to confirm full eligibility; include for full‑text review.
Study uses a simple motor task, not social processing, and includes participants with autism (a neurological/psychiatric disorder). These clearly violate the review’s inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of social cognition (mentalizing/inferring others' preferences) with whole-brain parametric analyses reported. Participants (n=64) appear to be healthy adults; no psychiatric/neurological disorders mentioned. Age range not specified in abstract but no exclusionary information. Meets inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to confirm ages.

Abstract centers on paranoid delusions, implying participants with psychiatric disorder; does not state healthy adult sample. Exclusion criterion: studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders. Insufficient evidence of healthy participants/whole-brain results.

The study reports fMRI results from two individuals with developmental phonagnosia (a neurological disorder). Exclusion criterion: studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric and/or neurological disorders. Although controls are included, the primary subjects are patients, so exclude.

This paper is a quantitative review/meta-analysis of fMRI studies in individuals at clinical high risk for psychosis (clinical population), not primary fMRI data from healthy adults. It is a meta-analysis and includes psychiatric participants, both grounds for exclusion per the criteria.

fMRI task examines social processing (third-party punishment) in lay adult participants; no indication participants had disorders. Abstract reports whole-brain activations but does not specify analysis type or age range; include for full-text review to confirm whole-brain and age criteria.

Study reports results from a patient with a neurological disorder (cerebellar tumor) and focuses on recovery after neurosurgery. Exclusion criterion: studies reporting results among participants with neurological disorders. Although healthy controls were included, presence of patient data warrants exclusion.

Participants are children and adolescents including individuals with Autism Spectrum Disorder (clinical population), not healthy adults (18–60). Study uses resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm. These clearly violate inclusion criteria.

Participants were children/adolescents (not adults 18–60) and included an autism spectrum disorder (clinical) group. Thus the sample is not healthy adults within the eligible age range; does not meet inclusion criteria.
Participants are children (mean age 10.2 years), outside the review's eligible adult age range (18–60). Although it uses fMRI and healthy participants, the age criterion clearly excludes this study.

Participants are adolescents (age 16–17), not adults aged 18–60 as required by the review. Although it uses fMRI and whole-brain analyses of social/introspective processing in healthy individuals, the sample falls outside the eligible age range.

Resting-state fMRI study (no social task) and includes participants with autism spectrum disorder (clinical population). Does not meet inclusion criteria of task-based social processing in healthy adults.

This is a meta-analysis of fMRI studies focusing on traumatic brain injury patients. Exclusion criteria: meta-analyses/systematic reviews and studies of participants with neurological disorders (TBI). The abstract indicates focus on TBI, so it meets exclusion criteria.

Study includes participants with high-functioning autism (clinical population) and reports resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm; does not meet healthy adults performing a social-related task.

Adult fMRI study (participants scanned at age 24) using a social task (friend vs stranger vs alone hand-holding during threat). Reports whole-brain activation across multiple regions; no clinical population mentioned.

Participants are children and adolescents (not adults 18-60) and include ASD (clinical) participants; the study thus fails the healthy adult population criterion. It also focuses on auditory processing/connectivity rather than an fMRI social-task. Exclude based on population and task mismatch.

fMRI study of social (mentalizing) task in healthy adult subjects; however abstract does not specify participant ages (18-60) and does not explicitly state whole-brain results versus ROI. Insufficient information to confirm all inclusion criteria — include for full-text review.

fMRI was used while participants viewed dynamic facial expressions (a social-processing task) and no clinical population is mentioned. However the abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state whole-brain results, so include for full-text review to confirm health, age range, and whole-brain analyses.

fMRI study of social cognition (comparing perceptions of close vs non-close others) reporting neural activations (OFC, ACC). No indication of clinical populations or that only ROI analyses were used. Abstract lacks explicit participant ages and full-brain statement, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study in healthy human participants involving an interactive social task (self- and other-initiated joint attention). Abstract reports brain-wide activity changes linked to social processing rather than ROI-only analyses. Participant sample described as healthy adults; meets inclusion criteria for social fMRI in healthy adults.

Human fMRI study of dynamic social attention cues (head turns) relevant to review. Participants likely healthy adults though ages/health not specified. Abstract does not clearly state whole-brain results (focuses on right STS), so insufficient info to exclude based on ROI reporting. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health and whole-brain analysis.

fMRI study in healthy adults viewing emotional/social movies (social-related processing). Reports whole-brain voxelwise intersubject correlations and network results, not ROI-only. No evidence of patient samples or being a review. Meets inclusion criteria; full text can confirm ages and health status if needed.

Abstract reports results from a sample including outpatients with schizophrenia (psychiatric disorder). Exclusion criteria disallow studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders, so the study should be excluded despite inclusion of healthy controls and use of fMRI social task.

fMRI study using a social task (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma with human partners) in adult men and women; large sample. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state whole-brain vs ROI analyses or confirm healthy status. No exclusion criteria are clearly met, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study of face emotion processing (a social task) in a community sample with high vs low social anhedonia; no psychiatric/neurological patients reported. Abstract reports group×condition effects in multiple brain regions (not described as ROI-only), consistent with whole-brain results. Age not specified but implies adult community sample. Include for full-text review to confirm age range and whole-brain analysis details.

Abstract reports an fMRI task involving self- vs other-serving decisions (social processing) in a healthy individual, but provides insufficient information on participant age and whether whole-brain analyses were reported. Single-case design is not an automatic exclusion. Include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study of social sharing (social-related task) in pairs of healthy adult friends; reports neural activity (ventral striatum, medial OFC). No indication of ROI-only analyses or clinical population; meets inclusion criteria for whole-brain fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

Participants are adolescents (not adults 18–60) and include a clinical group diagnosed with internet game addiction; thus the sample is not healthy adults and does not meet the review’s inclusion criteria.

fMRI was performed while participants completed social-related tasks (recollected and imagined guilt). Abstract reports whole-brain activations in affective and social-cognition regions (ACC, amygdala, mPFC, TP, precuneus), not ROI-only. No indication participants had psychiatric/neurological disorders. Age range not specified—include for full-text to confirm demographics and analysis details.

Abstract reports decoding of social cognition tasks using fMRI from the HCP (healthy adult) dataset and uses whole-brain intrinsic functional networks rather than ROI analyses. However, age range and explicit statement of whole-brain statistical results are not specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Study reports fMRI results from participants with borderline personality disorder (psychiatric sample). Exclusion criterion: studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders. Therefore excluded despite addressing social processing.

Study populations are patients with schizophrenia (psychiatric disorder), not healthy adults. This directly violates the inclusion criterion requiring healthy participants; thus the study should be excluded based on abstract.

Study reports results for participants with autism spectrum disorder (a psychiatric/neurodevelopmental disorder). The review’s exclusion criterion excludes studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric/neurological disorders, so this study must be excluded despite including typically developing controls.

Participants are school-age children (ages 9–13), not healthy adults aged 18–60 required by the review. Although the study uses task-based fMRI of social cognition, the participant age range clearly excludes it.

fMRI study of action observation (observing others’ effort), which qualifies as social-related processing; reports whole-brain BOLD effects and conjunction analyses across action execution and observation (not ROI-only); no indication of clinical populations. Abstract does not state participant ages (18–60), so include for full-text review to confirm age eligibility.

fMRI study probing mentalizing (social cognition) during listening to literary fiction, reporting neural activation differences across networks (implies whole-brain analysis). Participants appear to be healthy adults; no clinical samples or ROI-only analyses reported. Age range not specified in abstract—include for full-text verification of age and whole-brain reporting.

fMRI study of facial emotion processing (a social task) in subjects with high genetic load for schizophrenia; likely involves healthy relatives rather than diagnosed patients. Abstract does not specify participant ages or whether analyses reported whole‑brain results vs ROI. Insufficient info to exclude—include for full-text review.

Abstract reports a region-of-interest (ROI) analysis; the exclusion criteria rule out studies reporting ROI results. The abstract does not indicate whole-brain results or participant health/ages, so exclusion is warranted based on ROI reporting.

Study reports fMRI results from clinical populations (participants with autism spectrum disorder and schizotypal personality disorder). Exclusion criterion disallows studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders.

fMRI study of empathy (a social-related task) reporting activations in multiple whole-brain regions (insula, ACC, dmPFC, IFG) and connectivity. No indication participants had psychiatric/neurological disorders; participants described as typical (likely healthy adults). Age range not specified in abstract—include for full-text review to confirm demographics.

Study used real-time fMRI during a social interaction task (ultimatum game) in volunteers, reports whole-brain classification results across subjects, and does not indicate clinical/ROI-only samples. Abstract meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

Study used resting-state fMRI (no social-related task) and reports results from psychiatric patient groups (bipolar and borderline patients) alongside controls. Thus it fails the ‘task-based social processing in healthy adults’ inclusion criterion and meets exclusion for studies with psychiatric participants.

fMRI study of social processing (others’ physical and emotional pain) that reports whole-brain analyses. Abstract does not specify participant ages/health status or whether ROI results are supplementary only, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample (18–60) and that whole-brain results are primary.

Study reports fMRI results from an adult patient diagnosed with high-functioning ASD and developmental prosopagnosia. Presence of clinical participants violates exclusion criteria (psychiatric/neurological disorder), so exclude despite control subjects.

Participants are children, including an ASD clinical group (not healthy adults 18–60), and analyses focused on an a priori vmPFC ROI. These meet exclusion criteria (non-adult/clinical sample and ROI-based results).

Sample spans ages 6 through adulthood (includes children), not restricted to healthy adults aged 18–60. Although it uses whole-brain fMRI and a social-related face task, the participant age range fails the inclusion criterion.

fMRI study using a social gaze task (social vs nonsocial stimuli) assessing action control in humans; reports whole-brain recruitment (frontoparietal network, subcortical structures, ACC, IFG) rather than ROI-only results. Participant health/age not specified in abstract, but no indication of clinical sample. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and whole-brain analysis details.

fMRI study of social-related processing (empathy/affective appraisal) during observation of human and animal suffering; adult healthy groups implied (no psychiatric/neurological disorders reported); reports whole-brain activations across multiple regions (ACC, IFG, amygdala, etc.); not an ROI or review.

fMRI study examining processing of emotional facial expressions (a social task) in humans, reports whole-brain results. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state healthy adult sample, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility (age 18–60 and health status).

The study uses fMRI during emotional facial expression processing (social task) in young adults. However, abstract is unclear whether participants are all healthy (familial risk group vs controls) and does not state whether results are whole-brain or ROI. Insufficient detail to apply inclusion criteria confidently, so include for full-text review.

This is a resting-state connectivity study including participants with schizophrenia spectrum disorders and healthy controls, not a task-based fMRI of social processing. It therefore does not meet the social-task fMRI inclusion criterion and includes psychiatric participants, so exclude.

Abstract reports fMRI MVPA of social interactions in posterior temporal regions, so addresses the review objective. The abstract does not specify participant health/ages or whole-brain results and mentions ROIs, creating uncertainty. Insufficient information to rule out inclusion, so include for full-text review to check participant demographics and whether whole-brain analyses were reported.

Abstract reports data from patients with schizophrenia (13 patients) alongside controls. Exclusion criterion: studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders. Although task is social and whole-brain results are reported, inclusion of a clinical sample warrants exclusion based on criteria.

fMRI study examining neural representations of self (social cognition) during self-judgment tasks in presumably healthy cross-cultural adults. Abstract does not specify age range or whether analyses were whole-brain versus ROI-only. Insufficient detail to exclude, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and whole-brain results.

Study used functional MRI while healthy adult participants viewed others in pain (a social-related task). The abstract reports whole-brain activations (MCC/dMPFC, bilateral anterior insula, secondary somatosensory cortex), not ROI-only analyses. Participants are described as healthy adults and no clinical population is indicated. Meets inclusion criteria.

Study reports fMRI results from adults with velo‑cardio‑facial syndrome (a neurological/genetic disorder). Exclusion criterion: studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric and/or neurological disorders — therefore excluded despite healthy controls being present.

fMRI study where participants viewed faces of others in real-world social networks (social task). Whole-brain functional MRI data were collected and reported neural systems tracking popularity. No evidence of clinical populations; fits inclusion for social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study using a social task (Theory of Mind and empathy cartoons) in healthy adult volunteers (13 right-handed males) reporting whole-brain activations across multiple regions (medial PFC, TPJ, amygdala). No indication of ROI-only analyses or clinical populations. Age range not specified in abstract—include for full-text to confirm ages meet 18–60 criterion.

fMRI study in healthy volunteers performing a social interactive task (matching-pennies) with humans/agents; reports modulation across social brain regions (dorsal/ventral TPJ, mPFC, temporal pole) consistent with whole-brain results; no ROI-only analysis or clinical participants.
Study used resting-state fMRI (no task), so it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring a functional MRI scan during a social-related task.

fMRI study directly examining social cognition tasks (empathy, Theory of Mind, self-reference). Abstract reports distributed activations across prefrontal and temporal regions (implying whole-brain results), no indication of clinical participants or ROI-only analyses, and it is an original empirical study rather than a review.

fMRI study using point-light biological motion — a social-related visual task. Abstract reports cerebellar and STS whole-brain responses and connectivity analyses, and does not indicate clinical populations or ROI-only results. However, participant age range (18–60) and explicit statement of whole-brain reporting are not provided; include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Study uses fMRI to examine processing of human voices (socially relevant stimuli) during auditory perception in humans. Abstract does not state participant health/ages or whether whole-brain (vs ROI) analyses were reported, so full-text review is needed.

Study includes and reports results from participants with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (a neurological disorder). Exclusion criterion disallows studies reporting results among participants with neurological disorders, so exclude despite inclusion of healthy controls and social-cognition task.

fMRI study in normal (healthy) subjects performing passive observation of social interactions — a social-related task. Abstract reports whole-brain activation increases (not ROI). Ages not specified; include for full-text review to confirm age range and methods.

fMRI study with healthy human participants performing collaborative communicative retrieval — a social processing task. Abstract does not specify participant ages (18–60) or explicitly state whole-brain analyses vs ROI. No exclusion criteria met; include for full-text review to confirm age range and whole-brain results.

The abstract examines negative emotion processing but does not specify that the task was social, nor does it report participant health/ages or whole-brain analyses. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone—include for full-text review.

This article is a narrative review of genetics and neural-systems approaches in autism, not an original fMRI study. It is a systematic review/meta-discussion and does not report original fMRI data of healthy adults performing social tasks or whole-brain results, so it meets the exclusion criterion for reviews.

fMRI study during a social interaction task (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma) in healthy subjects; reports effects across multiple brain regions (precuneus, visual cortex, amygdala, insula, caudate), suggesting whole-brain analyses. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participants are adults 18–60 and that whole-brain results (not ROI-only) were reported.

Study reports fMRI data from two patients with bilateral amygdala lesions (a neurological condition). Exclusion criterion disallows studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric and/or neurological disorders. Although healthy control data are included, the presence of clinical participants warrants exclusion.
Participants are non-human (dogs), not healthy human adults 18–60, so outside review population. Additionally, analysis focused on the caudate nucleus (ROI) rather than reporting whole-brain results.

Includes participants with cocaine use (substance-use disorder); abstract reports fMRI results in cocaine users. Exclusion criterion: studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric and/or neurological disorders.

This paper is a meta-analysis of 12 fMRI studies (systematic review/meta-analysis) rather than a primary fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults; excluded per the criterion that systematic reviews/meta-analyses are not eligible.

Study includes participants with schizotypal personality traits (a psychiatric condition) and reports results for that clinical group. Exclusion criteria disallow studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric/neurological disorders, so exclude despite presence of non-SPD controls.

fMRI study where healthy late-adolescent participants (ages 18–22) observed risk-taking versus safe actions—an explicit social/emotional processing task. Whole-brain activation reported across multiple regions; no ROI-only analyses or clinical populations mentioned, meeting inclusion criteria.

Resting-state seed-based fMRI study in patients with multiple sclerosis (neurological disorder); not a task-based social processing study and participants are not healthy adults. Excluded based on participant clinical status and lack of a social task.

Study involves schizophrenia patients (psychiatric disorder) and nonpsychotic relatives; thus reports results among clinical participants. This does not meet the 'healthy participants only' criterion. Abstract does not confirm a healthy-only sample or whole-brain results.

Abstract reports results from patients with schizophrenia (and healthy controls). Exclusion criteria state studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders should be excluded. Although task and scanning are relevant, presence of a clinical group warrants exclusion based on the criteria.

The study includes participants with schizophrenia and reports patient-specific results and correlations with symptoms. The exclusion criteria disallow studies reporting results among psychiatric disorders. Although healthy controls are included, the presence of a clinical group meeting exclusion criterion leads to exclusion based on abstract information.

fMRI study examining social cognition (mirror neuron and mentalizing systems) during action observation under cognitive load. Abstract reports system-level activation (not ROI-only) and does not indicate clinical participants. Age range not specified, so include for full-text to confirm healthy adult sample and whole-brain results.

fMRI study using social-animation task in healthy adult women; reports changes in neural activation across early visual and dorsal-stream regions (whole-brain effects described). No indication of ROI-only analyses or clinical/psychiatric sample. Meets social-processing fMRI and healthy adult criteria; include for full-text review.

fMRI study of improvised joint social action in healthy (trained) adult dancers with whole-brain-style results reported in abstract. Participant ages not specified; thus include for full-text review to confirm age range and whole-brain analyses.

Abstract reports an fMRI study examining social cognition/emotion during legal decision-making (a social-related task). No exclusion criteria are clearly met. Participant health status/ages and whether analyses are whole-brain are not specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm these details.

fMRI study examining social interaction processing during naturalistic movie viewing in 34 healthy-seeming participants; not a review/meta, nor ROI-only. Abstract lacks explicit participant ages (18–60) and does not state whole-brain results, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

The study examines emotional sentence attribution in patients with schizophrenia (clinical population). Inclusion requires healthy adult participants and exclusion criteria disallow studies reporting results in psychiatric populations. Abstract provides no evidence of healthy adult whole-brain fMRI results; therefore exclude.

The study used functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS), not fMRI. Inclusion requires a functional MRI scan; although the task is social and likely healthy adults, the imaging modality does not meet inclusion criteria.

Participants are young children (4- and 6-year-olds); the study focuses on early childhood and comparisons to children rather than an adult sample. Does not meet inclusion criterion of healthy adult participants aged 18–60. Abstract does not report adult-only whole-brain social task results.

fMRI study of affective theory of mind (social processing) in healthy participants. Abstract describes task with emotional facial expressions and neural activations/connectivity. Abstract does not report participant ages (18–60) or explicitly state whole-brain results, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Abstract reports fMRI during an Implicit Association Test about adultery and a go/no-go task measuring prefrontal activity—social-related processing in healthy partnered males. No psychiatric/neurological disorders are mentioned. The abstract does not specify participant ages or whether analyses were whole-brain versus ROI, so full-text review is needed.

fMRI study of emotion recognition using facial expressions (social processing) in 29 healthy subjects. Abstract does not report participant ages (18–60 check) nor explicitly state whole-brain vs ROI analysis. No evidence of psychiatric/neurological samples. Insufficient detail on age range and whole-brain reporting — include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Not a task-based social fMRI study: uses resting-state fMRI rather than a social-related task. Also includes participants with autism spectrum condition (clinical population), so not a healthy-only sample. Therefore fails inclusion criteria.

fMRI was used during a social motor response learning task in 18 healthy subjects with reported activations across multiple brain regions (not limited to ROIs). Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participants are 18–60 and that results are whole-brain.

Abstract reports a neuroimaging study of interpersonal synchrony in healthy adult participants performing a social task; suggests whole-brain findings (brain areas implicated). Age range and explicit whole-brain vs ROI not stated, so include for full-text review to confirm imaging modality, participant ages (18–60), and whole-brain results.

Study uses fMRI during a social interaction task (pairs playing a deception game), matching the review objective. Abstract does not specify participant health/ages or whether whole-brain analyses were reported; insufficient detail to rule out exclusion criteria. Include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and whole-brain results.

fMRI study of social processing (different laughter types) with task manipulation (implicit vs explicit). Abstract does not specify participant health/ages or explicitly state whole-brain analyses, so information is insufficient to confirm inclusion based on abstract alone. Include for full-text review to verify healthy adult sample and whole-brain results.

fMRI study using EmpaToM manipulating empathy and ToM (social tasks) with healthy adult samples (N=90, N=178) and reports whole-brain neural networks and resting-state connectivity. Abstract does not explicitly state participant ages or health status; include for full-text review to confirm age range (18–60) and health criteria.

Abstract explicitly reports Region of Interest (ROI) analyses. One exclusion criterion is studies reporting ROI results; therefore exclude. The abstract also does not clearly state whole-brain results or participant health/ages, so inclusion cannot be confirmed.

fMRI study of social processing (direct vs. averted gaze) in healthy participants; meets task and population criteria. Abstract does not specify participant ages (18–60) or whether results derive from whole-brain analyses versus ROI; insufficient detail to exclude. Include for full-text review to confirm age range and whole-brain reporting.

Resting-state fMRI (no social-related task) and includes participants with social anxiety disorder (clinical population). Fails the requirement of task-based social processing in healthy adults; inclusion of psychiatric participants is an exclusion.

Participants are children (ages 7–12), not healthy adults aged 18–60 required by the review. Although it reports fMRI of social/empathy processing, the sample age clearly falls outside inclusion criteria.

Does not meet inclusion criteria: study used resting-state fMRI (no social task), participants are male adolescents with conduct disorder (clinical sample, not healthy adults aged 18–60). Whole-brain results irrelevant given other exclusions.

The study reports dual MEG (magnetoencephalography) hyperscanning, not functional MRI. The review requires fMRI scans during social-related tasks with whole-brain fMRI results; this abstract does not report fMRI data and therefore does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining neural responses to observed social interactions (third-person perspective). Abstract reports whole-brain activations (precuneus, frontoparietal, occipital) and connectivity analyses, not ROI-only. No indication of psychiatric/neurological patient sample. Fits inclusion for social processing in healthy adults; include for full-text review.

fMRI study with 22 healthy adult participants performing an affective (social) touch task; abstract reports whole-brain contrasts identifying a network including insula, STS, mPFC/dACC. No clinical populations and not limited to ROI analyses. Therefore meets inclusion criteria.

Study uses resting-state fMRI and reports findings in schizophrenia patients rather than healthy adults performing a social task. Not a task-based social fMRI study and includes clinical participants, so fails inclusion criteria.

fMRI BOLD study using affective and cognitive Theory of Mind tasks in healthy participants, addressing social processing. Abstract does not report participant ages (18-60 criterion unclear) nor explicitly state whole-brain versus ROI analyses. Insufficient information to confirm exclusion criteria, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study of observing social interactions (social vs individual actions) in humans, matching review objective. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state whole-brain results; no evidence of ROI-only analyses or clinical populations. Include for full-text review to verify healthy adult sample (18–60) and whole-brain reporting.

Study used resting-state fMRI (no task) following cTBS; inclusion requires fMRI during a social-related task. Although participants appear healthy, the absence of a task-based social processing paradigm excludes it.

Abstract reports fMRI effects on networks linked to social cognition/theory of mind, so relevant. However it does not state whether participants performed a social-related task, participant ages/health, or explicitly that whole-brain results were used. Key inclusion criteria are unclear, so include for full-text review.
Animal study using a rat model and resting-state fMRI; not conducted in human participants (age 18–60) and did not use a social-related task. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract mentions Theory of Mind and neuroimaging but does not specify that the study used fMRI, participant ages/health status, or whole-brain results. No exclusion criteria are clearly met. Insufficient information to determine eligibility, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study of social processing (empathic perspective-taking imagining loved-one vs stranger) in human participants; reports activations in ACC, insula, TPJ suggesting whole-brain results; no indication of clinical sample or ROI-only analyses.

fMRI study of healthy adult participants (MDs aged 25–37) performing a social task (doctor–patient interaction). Abstract reports brain activation in medial frontal regions during treatment, indicating whole-brain results rather than ROI-only analyses. No psychiatric/neurological participants reported.

fMRI study of social-related processing (erotic and fearful social scenes) in healthy young adults (male, likely 18–60). Abstract reports neural activation differences across brain regions (mesolimbic structures, amygdala) rather than ROI-only results. Whole-brain analysis not explicitly stated but findings imply whole-brain reporting; include for full-text review to confirm.

Abstract reports an fMRI study with a social-cognitive task in 25 healthy female participants and describes whole-brain activation in multiple regions (PCC, vMPFC, lingual gyrus, sensorimotor cortex). Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participants are within 18–60 and to verify whole-brain analysis details.

Study reports fMRI during self-reference vs reference-to-others (social cognition), meeting the review objective. Abstract does not specify participant health/age (18–60) or explicitly state whole-brain vs ROI analysis; therefore insufficient information to exclude. Include for full-text review to confirm sample characteristics and analysis scope.

fMRI study where healthy adult mothers viewed images of own vs unfamiliar child/dog (social-related processing). Abstract reports activation across multiple brain regions (midbrain, fusiform gyrus), consistent with whole-brain results; no indication of ROI-only analyses or clinical populations. Age not specified but participants are adult mothers. Therefore meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI BOLD response during an eyes task (social processing) but does not specify participants’ ages, whether they are healthy adults (18–60), or whether whole-brain results were reported vs ROI. Insufficient information to determine exclusion, so include for full-text review.

The study reports fMRI results from patients with bipolar disorder and schizophrenia (psychiatric populations). Inclusion requires healthy adult participants (18–60). The abstract does not indicate a healthy-only sample, so it meets an exclusion criterion and should be excluded.

Study used fMRI during a social cognition (Theory of Mind) task in healthy adult volunteers (18 males), reports whole-brain task-related activations across multiple regions (fusiform gyrus, TPJ, STG, precuneus), and does not involve psychiatric/neurological patient groups or ROI-only results.

fMRI study using a social gaze-following task with political in-group/out-group faces; reports whole-brain BOLD activations (left FEF, supramarginal gyrus, mid-cingulate, insula). No ROI-only analyses or clinical samples reported; include for full-text review.

Includes adults with high-functioning autism and reports results for the clinical group. Exclusion criterion disallows studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric/neurological disorders, so this study is not eligible despite using social-related fMRI tasks.

Study reports fMRI results for euthymic bipolar disorder patients (psychiatric population). Exclusion criteria disallow studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders, so it should be excluded despite inclusion of healthy controls.

Abstract describes an fMRI experiment during a social perception task (in-group/out-group action judgments) in presumably healthy adults, but does not specify participant ages or state whether whole-brain analyses were reported. Insufficient details to confirm all inclusion criteria, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study of social cognition (cooperation vs competition) in humans, matching review objective. Abstract does not specify participant ages/health status or explicitly state whole-brain results vs ROI-only, so insufficient to confirm exclusion criteria. Include for full-text review to verify healthy adult sample and whole-brain analyses.

Participants are patients with amnestic mild cognitive impairment (a neurological disorder), not healthy adults aged 18–60; this meets the exclusion criterion for studies with neurological disorders despite involving social/emotional processing.

Sample includes older adults aged 65–75 as well as younger adults; inclusion requires healthy participants aged 18–60. Although the study used fMRI during an empathy-for-pain (social) task and reports whole-brain activity, the age criterion is violated.

Study reports fMRI results from high-functioning adolescents with autism spectrum disorder versus typically developing adolescents (clinical and adolescent sample). Participants are not healthy adults (18–60), and the sample includes a psychiatric/neurological disorder—thus fails inclusion criteria.

Resting-state fMRI study (no task-based social processing). Participants include patients with mild cognitive impairment and Alzheimer’s disease (neurological disorders) and likely older adults, not healthy 18–60. Does not meet task, population, or relevance criteria.

fMRI study of empathy/perspective-taking (social cognition) in healthy adult participants; reports whole-brain activation patterns across multiple cortical and subcortical regions rather than ROI-only analyses. No clinical population or review; meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports results from patients with spinocerebellar ataxia (a neurological disorder). Exclusion criteria state studies reporting results among participants with neurological disorders should be excluded, so this mixed-sample study does not meet inclusion.

The study includes and reports results for participants with psychiatric disorders (ASD and schizophrenia) in addition to controls. Exclusion criteria disallow studies reporting results among clinical populations, so it is not eligible despite including healthy adults.

Study reports fMRI results from individuals with autism spectrum disorders (a clinical population). Review requires healthy participants aged 18–60 and excludes studies of psychiatric/neurological disorders, so this study should be excluded.

Event-related fMRI using dynamic social vs nonsocial gesture stimuli; reports widespread activations across mentalizing, amygdala, pSTS, fusiform, lateral occipital and precentral regions, indicating whole-brain results rather than ROI-only. No clinical or patient populations are mentioned. Although participant age range is not specified, the abstract provides sufficient detail to meet the review objective and warrants inclusion for full-text review.

Abstract reports an fMRI study manipulating social vs. nonsocial working memory (n-back) in humans with reported network-level effects (frontoparietal, social cognition, face-processing regions), implying whole-brain analyses and a social task. Participant health status and ages (18–60) are not specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Participants are adolescents (not within the required 18–60 adult range) and the study includes a clinical group with moderate–severe traumatic brain injury (a neurological disorder). Thus it does not meet the healthy adult participant criterion and meets exclusion criteria.

The study includes participants with schizophrenia (psychiatric disorder). Exclusion criterion disallows studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders, so it should be excluded despite including healthy controls.

Abstract reports fMRI results for a clinical sample (patients with bipolar disorder) in addition to healthy controls. Exclusion criterion disallows studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders, so this study should be excluded despite including healthy adults.

fMRI study using MVPA to examine neural representation of others' mental states (social cognition). Abstract reports patterns across multiple brain regions (MPFC, TPJ, ATL), suggesting whole-brain analyses. However participant health status and age range are not specified in the abstract, so full-text review is needed to confirm healthy adults (18–60) and whole-brain reporting.

fMRI study examining mirror neuron responses and emotion processing (social cognition). Abstract reports whole-brain repetition-suppression effects in SMA and rIFG rather than ROI-only results. Participants appear to be healthy (no disorders reported). Age range not specified in abstract—include for full-text review to confirm eligibility. No exclusion criteria are clearly met from the abstract.

Participants are children/adolescents aged 10–17, not healthy adults aged 18–60 required by the review inclusion criteria. Other criteria (fMRI social task, whole-brain results) met, but age criterion excludes the study.

Participants are preschool-aged children with Autism Spectrum Disorder (clinical population), not healthy adults; does not meet inclusion criteria of healthy participants aged 18–60. Exclude based on participant clinical status and age.

Abstract reports results from a sample including patients with autism spectrum disorder (psychiatric disorder). Exclusion criterion: studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric/neurological disorders. Although healthy controls are included, presence of clinical group leads to exclusion.

fMRI study using social tasks (Cyberball, Dictator Game) reporting whole-brain activations. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicit health status, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adults (18–60).

fMRI study using a social task (representing what another person sees/joint attention) and reports whole-brain analyses. No indication participants had psychiatric/neurological disorders. Age range not specified in abstract; unclear but insufficient to exclude, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adults aged 18–60.

Participants are people with anorexia nervosa (psychiatric disorder), whereas the review requires healthy adults 18–60. The study population therefore meets an exclusion criterion. Additionally, the task (body checking) is not clearly a social-processing task. Exclude based on participant diagnosis.

fMRI study of social cognition (empathy) in healthy adult participants (N=26) performing a social-related task (empathy-evoking film clips). Abstract does not state whole-brain results or specific ages; not enough information to exclude. Include for full-text review to confirm whole-brain analyses and age range.

This article is a systematic review/meta-analysis protocol rather than a primary fMRI study of healthy adults performing social tasks. Per exclusion criteria (systematic reviews or meta-analyses), it should be excluded.

Participants are adolescents aged 9–17, which falls outside the review’s required adult range (18–60). Although an fMRI social task was used and participants appear healthy, the age criterion is not met based on the abstract.

fMRI study of social processing (sharing a third person’s feelings) in 20 healthy volunteers reporting voxelwise ISPS and inter-area connectivity (whole-brain analyses). Abstract does not specify participant ages (18–60)—include for full-text review to confirm age range and other details.

Dual-fMRI study performing fMRI during cooperative and competitive social interactions using data-driven, whole-brain analyses (group-ICA and inter-subject correlation). No evidence of ROI-only analyses, reviews, or clinical samples in the abstract. Participant health/age not stated, so include for full-text verification of healthy adults (18–60) and whole-brain results.

fMRI study where healthy participants judged actions at different levels of abstraction, implicating mental-state reasoning and action-representation networks (social cognition). Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicit whole-brain reporting, but it reports cortical network activity (not ROI-only). Insufficient detail on ages/whole-brain in abstract, so include for full-text review.

The study includes participants with autism spectrum conditions (clinical population) and reports ROI analyses (‘Regions of interest within mentalizing circuitry were examined’). Both inclusion of a psychiatric/neurological disorder sample and use of ROI analyses meet exclusion criteria.

fMRI study on 16 healthy young women performing the Reading the Mind in the Eyes Test (a social cognitive task). Participants appear to be healthy adults within 18–60. Abstract does not indicate ROI-only analyses or clinical samples. Whole-brain reporting is unclear, so include for full-text review to confirm.

Abstract reports BOLD fMRI during a social task (viewing affiliation vs isolation images with pleasantness judgments), so it addresses the review objective. The abstract does not specify participant ages (only 'younger' and 'older' adults) nor explicitly state whole-brain versus ROI analyses. No evidence of clinical samples. Insufficient detail on age range and analysis type; include for full-text review.

fMRI study of social (and monetary) reward processing using an incentive delay task in young, healthy participants; reports whole-brain activations (ventral striatum, DMN, amygdala, fusiform) and correlations with Autism Quotient. No clinical/psychiatric sample and not ROI-only.

fMRI study of face perception (socially relevant) in human observers; abstract reports neural responses (FFA, STS, amygdala) rather than ROI-only results. Participant health/ages and explicit whole-brain analysis are not specified, so insufficient information to exclude. Include for full-text review to confirm sample characteristics and analysis type.

Task-free (resting-state) fMRI study; no social-related task was performed. Although participants are healthy adults, the study does not meet the inclusion criterion of an fMRI scan during a social task. Exclude based on abstract alone.

fMRI study using face and voice (social) stimuli in 20 participants; reports whole-brain analyses (regions and connectivity) and not an ROI or clinical sample. Abstract does not state participant ages/health explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm participants are healthy adults aged 18–60.

Abstract reports fMRI evaluation of whole-brain and hemispheric activation in normal adult volunteers viewing videos of social encounters, meeting social fMRI and whole-brain criteria. Age range (18–60) not specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and other details.

fMRI was used while participants performed a social task (sex-categorization of interacting person dyads). The abstract reports activations in multiple brain regions (high-level visual areas, pMTG, fusiform/body areas, insula), suggesting whole-brain results rather than ROI-only, and there is no indication of clinical populations. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and analysis scope.
Study includes participants with schizophrenia (psychiatric disorder) and reports region-of-interest (right fusiform face area) analyses rather than whole-brain results, violating inclusion criteria.

Participants are adult male incarcerated offenders (forensic/clinical sample), not healthy community adults aged 18–60; thus the study population does not meet the review’s healthy participant inclusion criterion.

Healthy adult sample (40 heterosexual males) underwent intranasal OXT/placebo during fMRI while receiving interpersonal touch (a social task). Abstract reports neural responses in multiple whole-brain regions (insula, precuneus, OFC, pregenual ACC). No ROI-only analyses or clinical population reported. Fits inclusion criteria; include for full-text extraction.

fMRI study of social processing (fear/gaze recognition) in healthy adult men from the general population with reported activations in amygdala, fusiform gyrus, and anterior superior temporal cortex. Abstract does not specify participants' ages (18-60) nor explicitly state whole-brain vs ROI analysis; include for full-text review to confirm age range and that whole-brain results are reported.

Study sample comprises children and adolescents (developmental sample), not healthy adults aged 18–60. Although it uses fMRI and a social task, the participant age range does not meet the inclusion criterion.

Abstract reports ROI analyses (left FFA sensitivity) and does not present whole-brain results. The exclusion criterion ‘results of region of interest (ROI) analyses’ is therefore met; exclude based on abstract.

fMRI study of social-emotional (guilt, embarrassment) evaluative processing in healthy volunteers reporting activations across multiple brain regions consistent with whole-brain results. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participants are 18–60 and that analyses are whole-brain rather than ROI.
Participants are preadolescents (age 11), not healthy adults aged 18-60 required by the review. Although an fMRI social task was used, the sample age falls outside inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports results from adults with autism spectrum disorder (clinical sample). Exclusion criterion disallows studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric/neurological disorders. Although healthy controls were included and whole-brain analysis reported, presence of ASD participants means the study is ineligible.

fMRI was used during a social interactive task (and comparison to non-social control); results report whole-brain networks (default mode and other regions). No indication of clinical samples or ROI-only analyses. Abstract does not state participant ages, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult (18–60) sample and whole-brain reporting.
Participants are individuals with schizophrenia (psychiatric disorder). Review requires healthy adults (18–60); therefore the study is excluded.

The sample includes individuals with psychotic disorders (adjudicated forensic psychiatric population). The review excludes studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders, so this study should be excluded.

fMRI measured neural responses during a social-related task (social reflection) in healthy subjects. No indication participants had psychiatric/neurological disorders. Abstract does not specify ages or explicitly state whole-brain vs ROI analyses; insufficient detail to exclude, so include for full-text review.

Participants are adults with Asperger syndrome (ASD), i.e., a psychiatric/neurodevelopmental disorder. Inclusion requires healthy participants; thus the study meets the exclusion criterion for clinical populations.

fMRI study examining neural responses during agentic self-evaluation and endorsement of others’ evaluations; reports whole-brain regression results. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages (18-60), so inclusion cannot be confirmed from abstract alone. Include for full-text review to verify healthy adult sample and age range.

Event-related fMRI study assessing trustworthiness judgments (a social task); reports BOLD signal changes in amygdala, insula, STS suggesting whole-brain findings. No indication of patient populations or ROI-only results. Abstract lacks explicit participant ages, so include for full-text verification of healthy adults 18–60 and whole-brain analysis.

High-resolution fMRI was used during a social interaction task (cyber-ball) assessing neural responses to includer/excluder faces. Participants appear to be healthy adults; results report multivariate classification in cortical regions. Whole-brain reporting not explicitly stated, so include for full-text review.

Hyperscanning fMRI used during a real-time joint-attention social interaction task, addressing social processing. Abstract implies whole-brain cross-brain connectivity analyses rather than ROI-only. Participant health and exact ages are not specified in the abstract, so inclusion for full-text review is warranted to confirm healthy adults (18–60) and whole-brain results.

fMRI study in human adults assessing self/friend/unfamiliar face and name recognition — a social-related task. Abstract reports activation across multiple cortical regions (e.g., inferior frontal, ventral occipitotemporal, temporoparietal, medial cortex), indicating whole-brain results rather than ROI-only. Not a review and involves healthy adults. Age range not specified in abstract; include for full-text confirmation.

Abstract describes an fMRI study of social interaction perception (point-light displays) in presumably healthy adults performing a social-related task. The abstract does not report participant ages or specify whole-brain vs ROI analyses. Insufficient information to confirm exclusion criteria, so include for full-text review.

Title and methods indicate a multilevel kernel density fMRI analysis (a meta-analysis of fMRI studies) rather than an original task-based fMRI study. Exclusion criterion: systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Study population are children with benign childhood epilepsy with centrotemporal spikes (a neurological disorder) rather than healthy adults; age and clinical status do not meet inclusion criteria (healthy participants aged 18–60).

The study investigates VLPFC white matter organization and memory retrieval networks using diffusion imaging and fMRI, not a social-related task. It does not address social processing in healthy adults; thus it does not meet the review objective.

Study includes participants with remitted major depressive disorder (clinical population), not only healthy adults; exclusion criterion 'participants with psychiatric disorders' is met. Abstract does describe social stimuli and fMRI, but presence of clinical group clearly excludes it.

The study includes participants with schizophrenia and reports results for this clinical group. Exclusion criteria disallow studies reporting results among psychiatric disorders; presence of a clinical sample therefore excludes it despite inclusion of healthy controls.

Study focuses on autism spectrum conditions (ASC) rather than healthy adults; participants with ASC meet exclusion criterion for psychiatric/neurological disorders. Abstract provides no indication of fMRI in healthy adults or whole-brain results. Exclude based on participant population.

Participants were stable outpatients with schizophrenia (a psychiatric disorder). Inclusion criterion requires healthy adults; therefore study must be excluded despite using fMRI during an emotion-recognition task.

fMRI study of social-related task (mimicry modulated by emotion and group membership). Imaging results report activations across multiple whole-brain regions (TPJ, premotor cortices, SPL, IPL, insula, MCC). No indication of ROI-only analyses, clinical populations, or review article. Participants appear to be healthy adults in a social psychology sample.

Abstract reports fMRI during perception of nonverbal emotional signals (a social-related task) and presents whole-brain hemodynamic responses (pSTS and other regions), not an ROI-only report. No clinical population is mentioned. Participant ages are not specified—include for full-text review to confirm ages (18–60) and whole-brain analysis details.
Participants are schizophrenia spectrum patients (psychiatric disorder), not healthy adults. This directly violates the inclusion criterion requiring healthy participants; therefore exclude.
Participants are adolescents (ages 12-15), not healthy adults aged 18-60 as required by the review objective. Age criterion alone is sufficient for exclusion.

fMRI study where participants read a suspenseful literary text and authors report activation in brain areas associated with social cognition; likely healthy adults and results appear whole-brain. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state whole-brain analysis, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Hyperscanning fMRI during joint attention (a social task) in healthy-sounding participants; reports activation of right anterior insular cortex and inter-individual synchronization suggesting whole-brain analysis. Not a review or clinical sample. Include for full-text to confirm participant ages (18–60) and that results are whole-brain rather than ROI.

The study used near-infrared spectroscopy (NIRS) rather than functional MRI, so it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring an fMRI scan. Participants are healthy adults and task is social, but modality excludes it.

Study used resting-state fMRI (no social-related task performed during scanning). The review requires a functional MRI scan while participants completed a social task; resting-state connectivity does not meet this inclusion criterion.

This is a review of seven structural/functional MRI studies conducted in ADHD samples (clinical population), not healthy adults; additionally it is a review article rather than a primary fMRI study of social processing in healthy participants. Therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of person perception where participants viewed faces with behavioral information (a social task). Authors report a whole-brain analysis. No indication of clinical populations or ROI-only analyses; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient detail for inclusion.

fMRI hyperscanning study of live vs. replay eye contact (a social task) in healthy adult pairs; reports whole-brain activations (ACC, AIC, cerebellum) and functional connectivity rather than ROI-only results. Age range not specified—include for full-text review to confirm participants meet 18–60 criterion and that full-brain analyses are reported.

Study uses fMRI during a social task (implicit attitudes toward politicians via IAT) and reports whole-brain activations (vmPFC, amygdala, fusiform, anterior PFC). Abstract does not state participant ages or explicit health status (18–60, healthy), so cannot confirm those criteria from abstract alone. Include for full-text review to verify participant health/age and whole-brain analysis details.

fMRI study with 20 healthy adult participants performing a social-communication task (watching narratives with co-speech gestures). Abstract reports whole-brain activation patterns (DMN, left MTG/IFG, anterior temporal cortex). No ROI-only analyses or clinical samples mentioned.

Study focuses on adolescents and response inhibition (not social processing in healthy adults). Abstract does not mention fMRI or a social task; participants are adolescents (outside 18–60) and context involves ADHD/GxE rather than healthy adult social fMRI. Excluded based on population and lack of relevant fMRI social-task data.

Study includes participants with first-episode schizophrenia (psychiatric disorder). Inclusion criteria require healthy adults only; any study reporting results in psychiatric participants must be excluded. The abstract indicates mixed sample (FES patients and healthy controls) and focuses on patient-related abnormalities.

Study does not investigate social-related task processing and appears to involve participants with familial/increased risk for psychotic disorder (clinical risk group), not healthy adults only. Abstract also focuses on network analysis rather than task-based fMRI of social cognition; insufficient match to inclusion criteria.

Resting-state fMRI (no social-related task); participants are severely obese patients (not healthy adult sample for inclusion); study does not report task-based social processing. Therefore it does not meet the review inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of perception of different laughter types—clearly a social-related task in humans; no indication participants had psychiatric/neurological disorders. Abstract does not specify participant ages (18–60) or explicitly state whole-brain (versus ROI) analyses. Include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study of social learning in healthy adult participants (N=26) performing a social task; abstract reports whole-brain learning-related prediction-error signals across cortical regions (not ROI-only) and does not involve clinical samples. Age range not specified in abstract — include for full-text verification.

Abstract reports results from participants with Autism Spectrum Disorder (psychiatric/neurological condition). Exclusion criteria disallow studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric and/or neurological disorders, so exclude despite inclusion of healthy controls.

Participants are individuals with a psychotic disorder (clinical population), which violates the inclusion criterion requiring healthy adults. Although the fMRI tasks are social (facial affect processing), the clinical sample requires exclusion.

Participants are children and include at least one participant with autism (clinical population). The study therefore does not involve healthy adults aged 18–60 and reports results from participants with a psychiatric/neurological disorder.

fMRI study in healthy ‘normal subjects’ performing a social communicative task (talking to an actor), reporting whole-brain activations across medial PFC, STS, TPJ, precuneus. Not an ROI-only analysis, not a review, and not a clinical sample. Sufficient abstract information to include for full-text data extraction.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing a social (Theory of Mind) task; reports activation of distinct brain regions across the whole ToM network (whole-brain findings implied). Not an ROI-only, review, or clinical sample.

This is a comparative review article discussing behavioral and evolutionary aspects of face perception across species. It is not an original fMRI study in healthy adult humans and does not report task-based human fMRI whole-brain results. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/reviews and lacks required fMRI human data.

Abstract reports fMRI investigations using a social Theory-of-Mind (Why/How) task in (presumably) healthy adult participants and describes whole-brain network activations consistent with ToM meta-analyses. No mention of ROI-only analyses or clinical populations. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and whole-brain reporting.
Study reports fMRI results from individuals with autism (a neurodevelopmental/psychiatric disorder). Review requires healthy adult participants (age 18–60); thus it meets exclusion criteria.

Study participants are adolescents with autism spectrum disorder (ASD), not healthy adults aged 18–60. The review requires fMRI studies in healthy adult participants; this study involves a psychiatric/neurological disorder and pediatric/adolescent sample, so it must be excluded.

fMRI study of social perception (viewing approaching characters with angry/happy expressions), reports activations in multiple brain regions (amygdala, STS, fusiform, MTG) consistent with whole-brain results, and participants appear to be healthy adults; age range not specified in abstract so include for full-text review to confirm ages (18–60).

Study uses resting-state fMRI to identify biomarkers for autism and involves participants with ASD (a psychiatric/neurodevelopmental disorder). It is not a task-based social processing fMRI study in healthy adults, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.
Participants are children/adolescents (ages 8–17), not healthy adults aged 18–60 required by the review. This clearly fails the age inclusion criterion.

Uses resting-state fMRI (no social-related task) and participants are ultra-high risk for psychosis (clinical population), not healthy adults 18-60. Does not meet task-based or healthy participant inclusion criteria.

Study includes participants with Social Phobia (psychiatric disorder). Exclusion criteria disallow studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders, so exclude despite fMRI social task and healthy control group.

Study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm. Inclusion requires a functional MRI during a social-related task; absence of a task makes it ineligible despite healthy adult sample and whole-brain analysis.

Study participants include adolescents and individuals with autism spectrum disorder (clinical population). Meta-analysis requires healthy adults aged 18–60; inclusion of a psychiatric/neurological disorder sample and non-adult participants clearly excludes this study.

fMRI study of social reputation processing in male and female subjects (social-related task). Participants appear to be healthy adults; no clinical population or review. Abstract does not state ROI-only analyses; reports imaging findings consistent with whole-brain results. Whole-brain status not fully explicit, but insufficient info to exclude—include for full-text review to confirm whole-brain reporting and participant ages.

Abstract reports fMRI during a social mimicry task in human participants and reports whole-network activations (mPFC, STS, IFG) with no clinical population mentioned. However participant ages and explicit statement of whole-brain analyses are not provided. Insufficient detail to confirm all inclusion criteria — include for full-text review.
Abstract reports fMRI comparisons including patients with schizophrenia and their unaffected siblings. Presence of participants with a psychiatric disorder (schizophrenia) meets exclusion criteria.
Participants were non-human (domestic dogs). The review requires fMRI studies in healthy adult human participants (age 18–60); this study does not meet that inclusion criterion.

fMRI study of a social interaction simulation with 28 participants; reports neural activation results (amygdala, hippocampus, nucleus accumbens, vmPFC) consistent with whole-brain analyses. No indication of clinical populations or ROI-only reporting. Meets review objective and inclusion criteria based on abstract.
