fMRI experiment involved a social attribution task (attributing awareness to a cartoon face) with reported bilateral TPJ activity and other areas, implying whole-brain results. Hyperscanning fMRI study of mutual gaze and joint attention — clearly a social task. Abstract implies healthy adults but does not state ages or explicitly that whole-brain results were reported. fMRI study of explicit emotion recognition (a social-related task) in healthy young adult males. Abstract reports an fMRI experiment on social cognition (imitation inhibition, self–other distinction, mental state attribution) with no indication of patient groups or ROI-only results. fMRI study scanning participants during tasks that manipulate abstract vs. concrete mindsets within social cognition; reports conjunction analysis and brain activations (implying whole-brain results). Not a task-based social fMRI study: uses resting-state fMRI. Participants include individuals at familial high-risk for schizophrenia (not all healthy). Analyses are ROI-to-ROI (region-of-interest) correlations rather than whole-brain results.

Abstract reports fMRI during an auditory task (listening to human footsteps) with activation in 'social cognition' area (pSTS), but it does not specify participants’ health/ages or explicitly state the task is social. fMRI study of social cognition: participants viewed photographs of social groups (social task). Abstract specifies investigation of hemodynamic activity in three a priori regions (STG, IFG, amygdala), indicating ROI-focused analyses and does not mention whole-brain results. fMRI study with social manipulation (peer observation) during tasks in young adults. Participants appear to be healthy; tasks involved social influence on decision-making. Study reports fMRI during a social-related task (maternal neural response to infant cry) in adult mothers, with whole-brain activation findings described (multiple brain regions). Participants are not healthy adults: sample consists of individuals with alcohol use disorder (a psychiatric disorder), and age range includes participants up to 66 years (>60). Thus excluded per criteria.

fMRI study with social cognition tasks (reasoning about mental states) in neurologically normal participants; reports whole-brain reciprocal activation/deactivation and resting-state analyses. This paper is a meta-analysis/systematic review of fMRI studies rather than an original fMRI study in healthy adults; exclusion criterion (systematic reviews or meta-analyses) is clearly met.

fMRI study of a social task (viewing a moral dilemma about kinship) with reported whole-brain inter-subject correlation results across cortical regions. Resting-state fMRI in a clinical pediatric ASD sample (toddlers), not a task-based social processing study in healthy adults. Excluded by participant population and lack of social task.

Study uses resting-state fMRI (no social-related task performed). Inclusion requires task-based fMRI while participants complete a social-related task; therefore it does not meet the primary inclusion criterion.

Study involves patients with amnestic mild cognitive impairment (a neurological disorder), not healthy adults; thus fails inclusion criterion requiring healthy participants. Abstract indicates clinical population, so excluded.

This is a review article summarizing lesion and fMRI literature rather than an original fMRI study. The abstract does not report an fMRI experiment with healthy adult participants, tasks, or whole-brain results. As a systematic review/meta-type paper, it meets the exclusion criterion for reviews.

The study examines neural correlates of emotional prosody comprehension (a social cognitive task) in presumably healthy adults, but the abstract does not explicitly state use of functional MRI, participant ages (18-60), or whole-brain results. fMRI study of interpersonal human touch (social-related task) in eight healthy adults; independent component analysis reported distributed networks including SI and multiple cortical regions, indicating whole-brain results. This is a narrative/review chapter evaluating amygdala findings across neurodevelopmental disorders, not a primary fMRI study in healthy adults. This publication is a quantitative meta-analysis/systematic review of fMRI and PET studies rather than an original functional MRI study of healthy adults; exclusion criterion met.

Study reports neural responses to others' suffering in healthy adults and links to altruistic behavior—addresses social processing. This is a review/book chapter summarizing developmental social neuroscience and social influence, not an original fMRI study. The abstract reports no fMRI methods, participants, tasks, or whole-brain results; it is a secondary/source review and thus excluded.

Study includes participants with Tourette syndrome (a neurological disorder). Exclusion criterion prohibits studies reporting results among participants with neurological disorders; thus it does not meet healthy-only sample requirement.

Participants are adolescents (developmental sample across phases of adolescence), not healthy adults aged 18–60 as required by the review inclusion criteria. Therefore the study population is outside the eligible age range.

fMRI BOLD study of self/other personality and memory judgments—clearly a social cognition task in healthy adults (no clinical sample mentioned). Abstract does not indicate ROI-only analyses, but whole-brain status and exact age range are not specified, so include for full-text review to confirm.

The study investigates emotional memory (recognition of previously studied photos) and nonconscious memory effects, not social-related processing. Although it uses fMRI in healthy adults and reports whole-brain effects, the task is not social in nature, so it does not meet the review objective.

fMRI study examining social-cognitive perception of animated agents; reports whole-brain neural correlates (mentalizing and motor regions). No evidence of clinical populations or ROI-only analyses. This paper is an activation likelihood estimation meta-analysis of fMRI studies (a meta-analysis), not an original fMRI study of participants; excluded per criterion disallowing systematic reviews or meta-analyses.

This article is a coordinate-based meta-analysis (activation likelihood estimation of 30 articles), not an original fMRI study of participants. It meets the exclusion criterion: systematic reviews or meta-analyses. Therefore excluded based on abstract alone.

fMRI study where participants rated naturalness of dyadic social interactions (social-related task). Explicit fMRI experiments of social cognition (mentalizing about groups and individuals). fMRI task contrasts anticipation of touching an animate (human) vs inanimate target—social processing—in healthy volunteers with reported whole-brain task-rest correlations. Participants are preschool-aged children with autism spectrum disorder (clinical population), not healthy adults aged 18-60. Does not meet population criterion; task and whole-brain criteria irrelevant given exclusion for clinical sample.

Study used fMRI while participants played the trustee in the Trust Game (a social task), included healthy adult participants, and analyzed task-related whole-brain networks via independent component analysis. No ROI-only, clinical, or review exclusion criteria are evident from the abstract.

Not an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. The paper reports qualitative focus-group and questionnaire data from adolescents (teen students) and discusses public engagement; no functional MRI task or whole-brain results are described.

Sample includes participants with psychiatric disorders (BPD and NSSI) in addition to healthy controls. Exclusion criteria state studies reporting results among psychiatric participants should be excluded, despite use of fMRI cyberball and whole-brain analysis.

Study participants are patients with schizophrenia (psychiatric disorder), not healthy adults. Additionally, the task is language comprehension rather than a social-related processing task. Fails inclusion criteria.

Participants are children/adolescents (not adults 18–60) and the sample includes individuals with ASD (a clinical/psychiatric group). The task is basic auditory/visual discrimination, not social processing. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI in healthy suggestible adults and reports activations across multiple brain regions (not clearly ROI-only). fMRI study of responses to conspecific (human) disgust facial expressions, a social-processing task; reports activation in multiple brain regions (insula, mPFC, PCC, TPJ, STS), implying whole-brain analysis rather than ROI-only; not a review and no clinical population mentioned. fMRI study using a gambling task manipulating outcomes for self, friend, and antagonist — clearly social-related processing. Participants described as healthy (N=31). Abstract describes an rTMS intervention (virtual lesion) rather than a functional MRI scan; does not report fMRI data collected during a social task. Therefore it fails the inclusion criterion requiring an fMRI scan.

Abstract describes an fMRI study of social gaze processing in adults, reporting whole-brain activations (parieto-frontal attentional network, pSTS, mPFC, precuneus). 7T fMRI rest-task-rest study in healthy participants using social (attachment narrative) auditory task; reports functional connectivity changes between caudate seed(s) and multiple cortical regions suggesting whole-brain FC results. fMRI study examining mental-state attribution to human vs computer-generated music (social cognition). fMRI study where participants judged social aspects of biological motion (point-light displays and human-like walkers), a social-related task. fMRI study of gender perception from faces (a social-related task) with human participants; reports whole-brain voxel-wise analyses in addition to ROI results. Participant health appears to be typical adults though age range not specified—include for full-text review to confirm demographics.

Participants are children with autism spectrum disorder (clinical population) rather than healthy adults aged 18–60. This violates inclusion criteria (healthy adults) and matches exclusion criteria (psychiatric/neurological disorder).

Study uses fMRI during a Trust Game (a social task) and reports whole-brain activations across multiple regions. Abstract reports fMRI activation (default mode network) during processing of human action sentences in healthy adults and does not indicate ROI-only analyses or clinical samples. Abstract reports an fMRI study targeting dynamic facial-expression processing (a social cognitive task) and uses neurofeedback in presumably healthy participants; however, it does not specify participant ages or whether whole-brain results (versus ROI-only) are reported. fMRI study of mentalizing, empathy and prosocial behavior (social tasks); abstract reports whole-brain activations (dmPFC, vlPFC, pain matrix) rather than ROI-only results. fMRI study of social evaluation (politicians) in healthy adults appears to fit the review objective. Abstract does not report participant ages or explicitly state whole-brain vs ROI analyses, so full-text review is needed to confirm eligibility.

Study reports fMRI during an empathy-for-pain social task and describes whole-brain activations (insula, aMCC, S1) and behavioral outcomes; no indication of clinical/psychiatric sample. Abstract reports an fMRI study of social evaluations fitting the review objective. It does not specify participant ages/health status or whether analyses were whole-brain vs ROI. No exclusion criteria are clearly met from the abstract; include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study where participants made social-category (stereotype) judgments during scanning; reports activations in social-cognition regions (mPFC, PCC, TPJ, anterior temporal cortex), indicating whole-brain analyses. Not an fMRI task study in healthy adults: uses structural MRI (cortical thickness/structural covariance) and includes participants with autism spectrum disorder (clinical population), so fails inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports a task involving social persuasion and functional MRI with whole-brain results (prefrontal, temporal cortices; hippocampus/parahippocampal gyrus; caudate). fMRI study examining perception of dynamic audio-visual emotional cues (a social-related task) with bimodal vs unimodal and emotional vs neutral conditions. fMRI study of social-related processing (observation of human/animal mouth actions) in healthy adult participants; abstract reports whole-brain activations/connectivity rather than ROI results. Review exclusion criterion excludes studies reporting results among psychiatric/neurological populations. Abstract lacks clear evidence of healthy-only sample or whole-brain fMRI results; exclusion is warranted.

fMRI study of social competition in humans, reports activation/deactivation in mPFC and precuneus/PCC (suggesting whole-brain results) and does not mention clinical populations or ROI-only analyses. Participant ages not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adults age 18–60 and whole-brain reporting.

fMRI study using a socio-emotional social-preference task (preference vs gender ID to faces) with whole-brain connectivity (PPI)/network analyses. No indication of clinical participants or ROI-only reporting. Age not specified in abstract, but meets social-related fMRI criteria; include for full-text confirmation of health and age range.

Study examines patients with behavioral variant frontotemporal dementia (neurological disorder), not healthy adults, and reports resting-state brain activity rather than fMRI during a social-related task. Fails core inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes face processing (a social domain) but focuses on development; age range and whether participants are adults (18–60) is unclear. The abstract does not specify fMRI task details or whether whole-brain results were reported. Insufficient information to exclude—include for full-text review.
Study includes participants with schizophrenia (reports results among a psychiatric sample) and uses region-of-interest analyses; both meet exclusion criteria for this review.

This is a review article of task-based neuroimaging in 22q11.2 deletion syndrome (patients), not an original fMRI study in healthy adults. It therefore meets exclusion criteria for being a review and for reporting results in a clinical population rather than healthy participants.

Event-related fMRI study of self-face recognition (social cognition) in healthy right-handed adult subjects; whole-brain contrasts reported showing activations/deactivations across distributed regions. No ROI-only analysis, no clinical population, and task is social-related. Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.

fMRI study of social-related processing (judgments of pride vs joy) in healthy volunteers; reports activations across multiple brain regions (implying whole-brain analysis). No indication of ROI-only analyses, clinical participants, or review article. Age range not specified—include for full-text verification.

fMRI study of social-concept judgments reporting bilateral superior anterior temporal and medial prefrontal activations (suggesting whole-brain results). Abstract does not specify participant age or explicitly state healthy adults. No clear ROI-only or patient-sample exclusion. Include for full-text review to confirm health/age and whole-brain analyses.

Event-related fMRI study examining processing of others' decisions (social cognition) in humans. Abstract does not specify participant ages or whether analyses were whole-brain vs ROI, so information is insufficient to exclude. Include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult samples and whole-brain results.

fMRI study of face identification (socially relevant task) reporting whole-brain functional activations contrasting false recognition vs. hits/correct rejections. No indication of psychiatric/neurological patients or ROI-only analyses. Abstract lacks explicit age range but implies healthy adult participants; include for full-text to confirm ages and methods.

fMRI study presenting dynamic facial expressions (a social-processing task) reporting whole-brain activations across reward- and threat-related regions. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state ‘healthy’ sample, so insufficient demographic/health detail — include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study examining amygdala responses to masked fearful eye cues—clearly a social-face processing task in humans. Abstract does not specify participant health/ages or whether whole-brain (vs ROI) results were reported, so include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

The study includes and reports results from participants with Huntington’s disease (a neurological disorder). The exclusion criteria disallow studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric/neurological disorders. Although healthy controls were included, the presence and focus on the patient group warrants exclusion based on the abstract alone.

fMRI social-cognitive task in healthy participants; no evidence of psychiatric/neurological samples. Abstract does not report participant ages (18–60 eligibility) nor specify whether results are whole-brain versus ROI-only. Insufficient information to determine exclusion, so include for full-text review.
This study used resting-state fMRI (not a task-based social-processing paradigm) and reports results from patients with schizophrenia (clinical sample), both of which violate inclusion criteria.

fMRI was performed while participants completed a social (speed-dating) task; participants appear to be healthy adults; abstract reports activations across multiple whole-brain regions (pSTS, RMPFC, affective regions) with no indication of ROI-only analyses or clinical populations. Sufficient information to include for full-text review.

The abstract describes a review/synthesis of multiple functional neuroimaging studies of deception rather than reporting original fMRI data on participants. It lacks participant details, task specifics, and whole-brain results; thus it meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Abstract does not report participant health/ages or state whole-brain results; it emphasizes face-selective regions but does not clearly state ROI-only analyses. Insufficient information to determine exclusion based on ROI analysis or participant criteria, so include for full-text review to assess eligibility.

Participants are preterm infants (31+6 to 36+3 weeks postmenstrual age), not healthy adults aged 18–60. The task is somatosensory mapping (wrist/ankle/mouth stimulation), not a social-related task. Therefore the study does not address the review population or the social-processing task criteria.

The article is a meta-analysis of 33 fMRI studies. The exclusion criteria explicitly exclude systematic reviews or meta-analyses; the abstract does not report original participant-level fMRI data, so it should be excluded.

fMRI study in which healthy adult observers watched videos of a violent social interaction (social-related task). Abstract reports whole-brain activation and connectivity across multiple regions (STS, EBA, amygdala, etc.) rather than ROI-only. Age range not specified, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

fMRI study of a social (empathy) task performed in the scanner with 34 healthy participants; reports activation across multiple brain regions (not limited to ROI), indicating whole-brain results. Abstract does not state participant ages explicitly; include for full-text review to confirm ages fall within 18–60 and confirm whole-brain analysis details.

Participants are children (10–15 years) and include a clinical autism group, not healthy adults aged 18–60. The task is auditory change detection (not a social-processing task). These violate the population and intervention/task eligibility criteria.

This article is a review of perceptual organization in schizophrenia (a systematic review), not an original fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. It is a review article and reports patient samples; thus it meets exclusion criteria (systematic reviews/meta-analyses and patient-focused studies).

Study reports fMRI results from participants with psychiatric disorders (schizophrenia and CD/ASPD). Exclusion criterion forbids studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric/neurological disorders, so this study should be excluded despite using a social task.

Study 2 reports fMRI data on neural responses during viewing of social targets (mental state attribution), using adult participants (heterosexual men mentioned) with no clinical populations. Abstract names multiple whole-brain regions (mPFC, PCC, temporal poles) rather than ROI-only results. Include for full-text review to confirm whole-brain analysis details and exact age range.

Participants include individuals with early psychosis (psychiatric disorder) and controls aged 13-19 (not healthy adults 18-60). Neuroimaging analyses are ROI-based rather than whole-brain. These meet multiple exclusion criteria (clinical sample, age outside target range, ROI results).

Abstract reports a functional MRI social closeness task in healthy participants and links SNS to functional brain activity. It does not specify participant ages (18–60) or explicitly state whole-brain vs. ROI analyses. Insufficient detail to confirm exclusions, so include for full-text review to verify age range and that results are whole-brain.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of interpersonal space (a social task) using intranasal oxytocin in a double-blind placebo-controlled design with presumed healthy adult participants; imaging results mention activity in social brain regions (dmPFC). Whole-brain analysis is not explicitly stated, so insufficient information to exclude. Include for full-text review to confirm whole-brain results and participant ages.

Abstract reports results from patients with schizophrenia (and their nonpsychotic siblings) in addition to healthy controls. The review excludes studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders; presence of a patient group therefore warrants exclusion. Whole-brain/ROI details are unclear, but exclusion criterion is clearly met.

fMRI study where healthy human subjects performed social-related tasks (gaze- and finger-directed attention). Abstract reports whole-brain BOLD responses (posterior STS, lingual gyrus). Participant ages not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm ages (18–60) and whole-brain reporting.

Participants are young children (ages 3–5), not healthy adults (18–60). Study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task involving social processing. Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criteria.
Participants are Latin-American preadolescents (under 18), whereas the review requires healthy adults aged 18–60. Age criterion is not met based on the abstract, so the study is excluded.

fMRI study of social cognition (theory of mind: cooperation vs deception) performed in healthy volunteers and reports activations across multiple brain regions (suggesting whole‑brain results). No indication of psychiatric/neurological samples or ROI‑only analyses. Abstract does not state participant ages (18–60), so full text should be checked for age eligibility.

fMRI study examining theory-of-mind/social vs non-social processing; reports whole-brain activation differences (dmPFC, precuneus, rTPJ). No evidence of clinical populations or ROI-only analyses in abstract. Age not specified but likely healthy adults; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and full-brain analysis details.

Study participants are adults with autism spectrum disorder (clinical population), not healthy adults. Additionally, the study reports resting-state connectivity and cerebellar morphometry rather than task-based fMRI during a social-related task. Thus it fails key inclusion criteria.

Task: fMRI observe/imitate emotional faces — a social-processing task. Participants: healthy adults (28 enrolled, 20 in final analyses). Analysis: whole-brain multivariate PLS identifying spatial activation patterns (not ROI). No psychiatric/neurological sample. Satisfies inclusion criteria.

This article is a review (not an original fMRI study) summarizing monkey and human work rather than reporting new fMRI data or whole-brain results from healthy adult participants. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses and provides insufficient primary fMRI outcome data for inclusion.

Study concerns participants with autism spectrum disorder (clinical population) and focuses on structural MRI and resting-state connectivity, not task-based fMRI of social processing in healthy adults. Meets exclusion for psychiatric/neurological disorder sample and does not report task-based whole-brain social fMRI results.

Participants are patients with borderline personality disorder (psychiatric population). Review exclusion criteria disallow studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders, so this study is excluded.

Participants are adolescents (developmental sample), not healthy adults aged 18–60. This fails the age criterion for inclusion in the review. (Abstract also does not clearly state whole-brain results.)

fMRI study examining social impression updating with reported activations across multiple brain regions (suggesting whole-brain analysis). No mention of clinical populations or ROI-only analyses. Participant age/health not specified in abstract—include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study of social cognition (predicting others' behavior) in 18 healthy participants; no indication of psychiatric/neurological sample or ROI-only analyses. Abstract does not report participant ages (18–60 criterion) or explicitly state whole-brain results, so include for full-text review to confirm these details.

fMRI study where 14 subjects viewed eye stimuli with dynamic pupillary feedback—a social processing task in healthy adults. Abstract reports activations across multiple brain regions (fusiform, STS, amygdala, insula, ACC), with no ROI or patient-group exclusions. Age range and explicit whole-brain statement not given, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Study includes participants with autism spectrum conditions (clinical population) alongside controls. The exclusion criteria disallow studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric/neurological disorders, so this study should be excluded.

Abstract reports analyses focused on 'individually defined fusiform face area (FFA)' with results described in left and right FFA; no mention of whole-brain results. This indicates ROI-based analysis, which meets the exclusion criterion.

fMRI measured neural responses during observation of human actions (mirror-system/social cognition task) in healthy adults; abstract reports neural activity differences across brain areas (implying whole-brain results) and does not indicate ROI-only analyses or clinical populations.

The study reports fMRI results from patients with schizophrenia (psychiatric participants). The exclusion criterion disallows studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders. Although healthy controls are included, the presence of patients leads to exclusion.

Abstract lacks key details: it does not explicitly state that an fMRI was used during a social task, whether participants were healthy adults (psychopathic traits could be in clinical or nonclinical samples), or whether whole-brain results are reported. Insufficient information to apply inclusion/exclusion—include for full-text review to verify methods and sample.
Abstract identifies the paper as a review of model-based fMRI approaches and applications; it is not an original fMRI study. Per exclusion criteria (systematic reviews/meta-analyses), exclude.

Participants are autistic adolescents (clinical population), not healthy adults (18–60). Study includes participants with autism (exclusion) and reports ROI analyses; does not meet inclusion criteria for healthy adult whole-brain fMRI.

The study includes participants with autism spectrum disorder (a psychiatric/neurodevelopmental condition). Exclusion criterion states studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric and/or neurological disorders should be excluded.

Study includes participants with schizophrenia (psychiatric disorder), meeting exclusion criterion 'studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric and/or neurological disorders.' Abstract also indicates use of ROIs (listening condition used to create ROIs), raising potential ROI-analysis exclusion.

Functional MRI study of social trait judgments (trustworthiness, attractiveness) in 44 healthy adult participants; reports whole-brain hemodynamic activations (dmPFC, IPC) rather than ROI-only analyses. Not a review/meta-analysis and participants are healthy—meets inclusion criteria.

The study reports results from participants with autism spectrum conditions (a neurodevelopmental/psychiatric disorder). The exclusion criteria disallow studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric and/or neurological disorders, so the paper should be excluded despite including healthy controls.

Includes participants with autism spectrum disorder (psychiatric/neurological disorder) rather than only healthy adults; task assesses monetary/object reward processing rather than social-related processing. Therefore does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI during a social provocation/aggression task (Taylor aggression paradigm) in healthy adult males. Abstract does not report participant ages (18-60) nor explicitly state whole-brain vs ROI analyses. Insufficient information to confirm those criteria from abstract alone — include for full-text review.

Participants ranged from 7–40 years, so the sample includes minors and is not restricted to healthy adults aged 18–60 as required. Abstract gives no indication of adult-only subgroup or analyses; therefore does not meet the age-based inclusion criterion.

Abstract reports results for participants with autism spectrum disorder (ASD). Exclusion criterion: studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric/neurological disorders. Therefore the study should be excluded. (Whole-brain status unclear but exclusion is already met.)

Resting-state fMRI in young children (mean age ~5) including participants with ASD; not a task-based social-processing fMRI study and participants are not healthy adults aged 18–60. Therefore does not meet inclusion criteria.

This article is a multi-method review/meta-analysis (Neuroscience and Biobehavioral Reviews) synthesizing lesion, TMS, MVPA, and Neurosynth evidence rather than reporting new primary fMRI data from participants. Exclusion criterion: systematic reviews or meta-analyses.

Abstract reports results for patients with borderline personality disorder as well as healthy controls. Exclusion criterion specifies studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders; therefore exclude despite whole-brain analyses.

fMRI study using a passive viewing (social) task on racial prejudice/disgust perception. Abstract reports neural activations and functional couplings (insula, amygdala, ACC) suggesting whole-brain analyses; no ROI-only approach or clinical samples mentioned. Age range not specified, but participants likely healthy adults. Insufficient detail on age and explicit whole-brain reporting warrants full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study examining prosodic decoding of communicative intentions (a social task). Abstract reports whole-brain activations (ventral auditory stream, amygdala, mentalizing system) and does not indicate ROI-only analyses, clinical samples, or that it is a review. Participant health and ages are not specified in the abstract, so include for full-text confirmation.

The study reports results from participants with psychiatric history (euthymic women with prior depression and suicidal behavior). Exclusion criteria forbid studies reporting results among psychiatric participants; thus it does not meet the 'healthy adults' requirement.

fMRI study with healthy subjects performing a social-related task (familiarity judgments for personally familiar, famous, and unfamiliar faces). Abstract reports whole-brain activation/suppression across multiple regions (not ROI-only). Not a review and involves healthy adults; meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study using social-related tasks (gender identification of angry and happy faces) in adult participants (N=30); reports whole-brain activations (amygdala, fronto-parietal). No mention of psychiatric/neurological disorders. Age range not specified—include for full-text verification.

Study includes and reports results from patients with schizophrenia (psychiatric disorder). Exclusion criteria disallow studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric/neurological disorders, so it should be excluded despite having healthy controls.

fMRI study examining neural responses to faces varying by race and socioeconomic status—clearly a social processing task in healthy adult participants (61 white males). Abstract indicates multivariate whole-brain analysis approach (partial least squares), though exact age range and explicit statement of whole-brain results are not given. Include for full-text review to confirm age criteria (18–60) and that whole-brain results (not ROI-only) are reported.

Study used fMRI during an emotional face-recognition task (social processing) in adult mothers described as without current mental disorders; abstract reports whole-brain activation differences. Fits inclusion criteria for healthy adults (18–60 likely), social task, and whole-brain results.
Participants are adolescents (13 years old), outside the required healthy adult age range (18–60), so the study does not meet the inclusion criteria.

fMRI study investigating integration of face and voice emotional expressions (social processing). Abstract reports a whole-brain approach identifying rpSTS responses; although ROIs were also used, whole-brain results are presented. Participants appear to be healthy adults (no disorders mentioned). Age range not specified—include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study in healthy adult college fans performing an emotional memory retrieval task tied to social identity (fan perspective) and social cognition; abstract reports whole-brain hemodynamic results across many regions (not ROI-only). No clinical population or review article. Therefore meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI studies examined persuasion (a social-cognitive task) in healthy adult samples across two cultural groups and media. Abstract reports whole-brain activation in a consistent network (Studies 1–2); although Study 3 used ROI analyses, whole-brain results are clearly described. No clinical populations mentioned.

Study includes Huntington’s disease gene carriers (a neurological disorder). Inclusion criteria require healthy participants only (age 18–60). Presence of a clinical population clearly meets exclusion criteria, so exclude despite whole-brain fMRI and social/emotional task.

fMRI study probing social-related processing (animacy/mentalizing) using animated stimuli; abstract reports whole-brain activations across social neural network and mirror neuron system. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicit statement of ‘healthy’ status, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study using a social task (viewing partner emotional videos and reflecting on self/other), healthy adult participants (monogamous relationships; no clinical population reported), and whole-brain activation results reported (lists of brain regions). No ROI-only analyses or reviews indicated.

fMRI study of healthy adult football supporters performing a social-related task (watching matches) examining neural correlates of group bias. Abstract reports whole-brain intersubject correlation results and group differences in frontal/subcortical networks (not ROI-based). No indication of clinical populations or that this is a review. Include for full-text review.

The fMRI task assessed anticipation/fear of movement (viewing/rating back-straining exercises), not a social-related task. The sample included chronic low back pain patients (with healthy controls), so it is not a study of healthy adults only. Abstract does not clearly report a social-processing whole-brain analysis relevant to the review objective.

This study used resting-state fMRI (no social-related task) and includes a clinical Williams syndrome group (a neurodevelopmental disorder). It therefore does not meet the requirement of task-based social processing in healthy adults.

The study includes participants with chronic cocaine use (a substance use disorder), i.e., a clinical population. This violates the criterion requiring healthy participants; therefore it should be excluded.

This article is a quantitative meta-analysis of 35 fMRI studies (systematic review/meta-analysis). The exclusion criteria explicitly exclude meta-analyses/systematic reviews, and the abstract does not report primary fMRI results from individual healthy participants.

Resting-state fMRI (no social-related task), includes participants with schizophrenia (clinical sample), and reports ROI/seed-based connectivity analyses. Does not meet inclusion requirement of task-based fMRI in healthy adults with whole-brain results.

The study used resting-state fMRI (no social-related task). Inclusion requires a task-based fMRI during social processing in healthy adults; although participants are healthy, the key task criterion is unmet, so exclude.

Functional MRI study where participants observed social interactions (social-related task). Reports whole-brain analyses (alongside ROI), and participants (n=27) appear to be healthy adults. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm ages and health status.

fMRI study in healthy adults using a socio-affective task (witnessing others' distress) assessing neural responses to compassion training vs control; reports activations across multiple brain regions (suggesting whole-brain analysis). Not a review and no patient population. Abstract does not specify exact age range or explicitly state 'whole-brain', so include for full-text review to confirm these details.

Study examines mirror neuron system function in individuals with schizophrenia (psychiatric population), not healthy adults. This meets the exclusion criterion of reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders.

fMRI study where participants imagined personally familiar others (a social task). Abstract reports person-specific patterns distributed across many brain regions/social brain network (suggests whole-brain analyses). No indication of clinical population or ROI-only results. Thus meets inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and details.

Abstract reports original fMRI experiments using dynamic vs static facial expressions (a social processing task) and reports whole-brain activations and ALE meta-analysis. Health status and participant ages not specified in abstract, but no clinical sample indicated. Include for full-text review to confirm participants are healthy adults (18–60) and that whole-brain results meet criteria.

Resting-state fMRI in participants with Williams syndrome (a neurodevelopmental disorder) and matched controls — not a task-based social-processing study. Includes clinical population (WS) rather than only healthy adults, and no social task reported; therefore does not meet inclusion criteria.

Participants are Clinical High Risk (CHR) for psychosis — a clinical population, not healthy adults. This violates inclusion criterion of healthy participants; exclusion is clear from the abstract. (Whole-brain reporting not specified but unnecessary given clinical sample.)

Includes participants with autism (a clinical psychiatric condition), which violates the exclusion criterion for studies of clinical populations. Also the task (Embedded Figures Task) is perceptual, not a social-related task.

Resting-state fMRI study in adolescents (includes autistic participants), not a task-based social-processing fMRI in healthy adults 18–60. Includes clinical population (ASD) and participants outside age range, so fails inclusion criteria.
Abstract reports discovery sample that included patients with mental illness. Exclusion criterion disallows studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders; therefore exclude.

Study includes participants with autism spectrum disorder (psychiatric condition) and a mixed sample aged 12–31 (includes minors <18). Thus it is not a study of only healthy adults 18–60 and reports results among a clinical group, meeting exclusion criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI investigation of social information sharing (a social-related task) in what appears to be healthy adults and does not indicate exclusionary ROI-only analyses or clinical samples. However, the abstract does not specify whether whole-brain results were reported. Insufficient detail to confirm whole-brain reporting, so include for full-text review.

Abstract reports results from participants with autism spectrum disorder (a psychiatric/neurological condition). Inclusion criteria require healthy participants only; presence of ASD participants meets an exclusion criterion. (Abstract also mentions ROI analyses, reinforcing exclusion.)

Study includes participants diagnosed with autism (a neurodevelopmental/psychiatric disorder), which violates the healthy-participants criterion. Additionally, the task is sensorimotor (eye movements), not social processing. Therefore excluded.

Resting-state fMRI study (no social-related task) and reports results in participants with psychiatric disorders (schizophrenia and ASD). Does not meet inclusion criteria of task-based social processing in healthy adults.

Abstract reports results from people with autism spectrum conditions (ASC) and their unaffected siblings, i.e. includes participants with a psychiatric/neurodevelopmental disorder. This meets the exclusion criterion for studies reporting results among disordered participants; abstract also lacks clear confirmation of healthy adult-only sample or whole-brain analyses.

fMRI study using emotional face processing during a gender-discrimination task (socially relevant). Participants appear to be healthy genotype groups (no psychiatric/neurological disorders reported). Findings discuss regional responses and network connectivity rather than ROI-only results. The abstract does not explicitly state whole-brain reporting or participant ages, so include for full-text review to confirm whole-brain analyses and age range.

fMRI study of action observation and motor pantomime (social-related processing) in congenitally blind and sighted adults. Abstract reports whole-brain activations across mirror system areas and does not state ROI-only analyses or clinical populations. However, participant ages and explicit statement of whole-brain analysis are not specified in the abstract — include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI was used while healthy adult participants made social-interaction decisions (free vs controlled by another person). Participants are healthy adults; study reports whole-brain functional connectivity findings rather than ROI-only analyses. No exclusion criteria met.
Participants are young children with autism spectrum disorder (clinical population), not healthy adults aged 18–60. Study therefore does not meet the population criterion for inclusion.

Event-related fMRI study of affective speech comprehension (social cognition task). Sample of 51 participants; no indication of psychiatric/neurological disorders or ROI-only analyses. Abstract does not state participant ages (18–60) or explicitly confirm whole-brain results, so insufficient detail to confirm all inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to verify age range and whole-brain reporting.

Two fMRI experiments examining perception of social actions in LOTC in (presumably) healthy participants. Abstract describes social-related task and original data (not a review). It does not state ROI-only results or clinical samples, but does not clearly report whole-brain coverage—insufficient detail to exclude. Include for full-text review to confirm whole-brain results and participant ages.

fMRI study of socially-induced cognitive emotion regulation (psychotherapist-led) in adult participants; reports whole-brain activations across DMN and comparisons with rest and non-social regulation, with no indication of clinical samples or ROI-only analyses. Fits social-related processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study of social/emotion attribution tasks (SELF vs OTHER) reporting whole-brain activations in healthy adult subjects. Abstract does not state participant ages (18–60), so include for full-text review to confirm age range and health status.

fMRI study examining anticipatory interpersonal touch—clearly a social-related task—and reports whole-brain activation differences (somatosensory cortex, mPFC, cerebellum, parietal and occipito-temporal cortices). No indication of ROI-only analyses, reviews, or clinical populations. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state 'healthy adults,' so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility (age 18–60 and health status).

Abstract reports fMRI investigation of emotion processing (a social-related task) in unaffected siblings (healthy, at-risk adults). However age range and whether whole-brain vs ROI analyses were used are not specified in the abstract — include for full-text review to confirm.

fMRI study of mothers viewing own and standard infant videos — a social-processing task in adults. Participants appear to be healthy mothers, but the abstract does not report ages or explicitly state whole-brain (vs ROI) analyses. Insufficient detail to confirm all inclusion criteria, so include for full-text review to verify age range and whole-brain results.

This article is a systematic review and meta-analyses of fMRI studies (not a primary fMRI study). Per the exclusion criteria, systematic reviews/meta-analyses are excluded. The abstract does not present original fMRI data on healthy adults, so exclusion is clear from the abstract.

This is a narrative review of neuroimaging in autism, not an original fMRI study. It does not report fMRI results in healthy adults performing social tasks and meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses (and involves a clinical population).

fMRI study of face perception (socially relevant) in healthy human participants; abstract does not report participant ages (18–60) nor explicitly state whole-brain results and refers to face-selective regions (possible ROI). Insufficient information to apply exclusion criteria confidently, so include for full-text review.

Study includes participants with schizophrenia (clinical population) and reports resting-state fMRI connectivity rather than a task-based functional MRI during a social-related task. These do not meet the review’s inclusion criteria (healthy adults performing a social task with task fMRI and whole-brain results).

The study used EEG (electrophysiological) methods rather than functional MRI; abstract does not report any fMRI whole-brain results. Therefore it fails the inclusion criterion requiring an fMRI scan during a social-related task.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of social influence (expert advice) on decision making and includes adult participants (18+), likely healthy. The task is social-related and neural correlates across multiple brain regions are reported. However, the abstract does not explicitly state whether whole-brain results (vs. ROI-only) were used. Include for full-text review to confirm whole-brain analyses and participant health criteria.

Non-human study: mouse resting-state fMRI with structural connectome; not a task-based fMRI of social processing in human adults. Does not meet population (humans 18-60) or task-based social processing criteria.

fMRI study of social cognition (theory of mind about emotions, beliefs, pain) in 46 volunteers, healthy sample implied; uses whole-brain multivoxel pattern analysis and reports activation across multiple brain regions. Abstract does not state participant ages or explicitly confirm whole-brain vs ROI-only results, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study of joint attention (social cognitive task) reporting whole-brain conjunction analyses identifying frontotemporoparietal networks; no indication of clinical populations or ROI-only analyses. Abstract does not state ages explicitly but implies healthy adult participants—warrants inclusion for full-text review.

fMRI study of auditory emotion discrimination (a social-related task) in human listeners. Abstract implies healthy participants and reports neural responses (amygdala and auditory cortex), but does not specify whole-brain vs ROI analyses. Insufficient detail to rule out ROI-only or exclude; include for full-text review to confirm whole-brain results and participant ages.

fMRI study examining social processing (similarity/closeness) in healthy adult participants (n=98). Tasks involve making inferences/judgments about self, friends, and others while scanning. No indication of patient groups or that results are ROI-only; appears to report whole-brain BOLD responses. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria for full-text review.

This study investigates birdsong and fMRI in songbirds (non-human). It does not report functional MRI in healthy human adults performing a social-related task, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria for human social-processing fMRI studies.

The study includes participants with anorexia nervosa (currently ill and in recovery), a psychiatric disorder. Presence of psychiatric participants meets the exclusion criterion despite inclusion of healthy controls and whole-brain fMRI.

The study used disruptive transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) during a perspective-taking task rather than functional MRI. It therefore does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring a functional MRI scan, so it should be excluded.

Abstract reports fMRI responses to romantic (social) stimuli and lists whole-brain activation in multiple regions. Participant health status and exact ages (18–60) are not specified in the abstract. Because the task is social and whole-brain results are reported but key eligibility details are unclear, include for full-text review to confirm age and health.

fMRI study presenting masked emotional (sad/happy) faces — a social-related task — in a sample of 51 healthy adults; reports whole-brain activations (amygdala, insula, occipito-temporal, somatosensory cortices). Abstract does not state participant ages (18–60), so include for full-text review to confirm age range and that analyses are whole-brain rather than ROI.

Study focuses on participants with Borderline Personality Disorder (a psychiatric disorder). Inclusion requires healthy adults only. Abstract indicates clinical sample, so it meets the exclusion criterion reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders.

Sample includes early adolescents (ages 11–14) alongside adults; does not meet requirement for healthy participants aged 18–60 only. Abstract also reports ROI analyses (ventral striatum), further reducing applicability to whole-brain adult-focused review.

fMRI study where healthy participants freely watched film scenes evoking emotional conflicts — a social/emotional processing task. Authors report whole-brain findings (multiple cortical/subcortical regions), but abstract omits participant ages and explicit whole-brain vs ROI statement; include for full-text review.

fMRI study in healthy subjects reporting whole-brain analyses and no ROI-only results. Abstract does not explicitly state participants' ages (18–60) or that the task is social-related; self/other feedback recognition could be social but is ambiguous. Insufficient information to confirm social-task and age criteria, so include for full-text review.

This is a narrative review of neural mechanisms in ASD, not an original fMRI study in healthy adults. It reports findings in participants with autism and is a review article, meeting exclusion criteria (review/meta-analysis and clinical population).

Abstract does not specify use of fMRI, the task, participant ages/health, or whether whole-brain results were reported. Topic (parental brain/biobehavioral synchrony) is relevant to social processing, but information is insufficient to determine eligibility; include for full-text review to assess imaging modality, sample health/ages, task, and analysis type.

fMRI study of social perception (eye gaze) in typically developing adults; reports neural responses across multiple whole-brain regions (pSTS, IPS, TPJ, amygdala, MT/V5). Participants are non‑ASD typical adults. Abstract indicates whole‑brain findings rather than ROI-only analyses and does not involve clinical populations. Thus meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study in which participants performed a social task (emotion recognition from dynamic gait/avatars). Abstract reports whole-brain activations (EBA, FBA, STS, amygdala) and does not indicate psychiatric/neurological populations. Participant ages not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm the 18–60 healthy adult criterion.

Study reports fMRI in healthy adult participants performing a social-related task (receiving negative social feedback). Participants are healthy (no psychiatric/neurological disorders). Abstract describes whole-brain activations (multiple brain regions), not ROI-only analyses. Thus meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI was used during a social interaction (social-related task) and participants appear to be healthy; however the abstract does not specify participant ages (18–60) or explicitly state whole-brain versus ROI analyses. Insufficient detail to confirm all inclusion criteria — include for full-text review to verify health/age range and whole-brain results.

The study used positron emission tomography (PET) rather than functional MRI, so it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring an fMRI scan. Although the task involves social deception and participants appear healthy, the imaging modality excludes it.

The study used resting-state fMRI (rsFC) rather than a task-based fMRI involving social-related processing. Inclusion requires functional MRI during a social-related task; although it examines peer/parent relationships, no social task was administered. Therefore it does not meet the primary inclusion criterion.

fMRI study using a social rejection task (Cyberball) with healthy participants including an adult group (n=16). Abstract reports whole-brain activations and adult vs adolescent comparisons, so adult whole-brain data likely available; include for full-text review.

Abstract reports fMRI imaging during an emotional face-processing task (a social-related task) and links OXTR methylation to neural activity in amygdala, fusiform, insula and functional coupling—indicative of whole-brain results. Participants are described as humans with no mention of psychiatric/neurological disorders. Age range not specified, but no exclusion criteria are clearly met from the abstract.
Participants are middle-childhood children (ages 8–12), not healthy adults aged 18–60 required by the review. Although it uses fMRI of social interaction, the age mismatch clearly excludes the study.

Participants are adolescents with autism spectrum condition and their siblings (minors and clinical population). This study includes ASC patients and non-adult participants, failing the inclusion criteria for healthy adults aged 18–60 and exclusion of psychiatric/neurological disorders.

Study reports results from participants with psychiatric disorders (patients with social and/or panic anxiety disorder). Exclusion criterion prohibits studies reporting results among psychiatric/neurological patients, so exclude despite inclusion of healthy controls and a social-related task.

Randomized, placebo-controlled fMRI study using a social interaction task (Prisoner’s Dilemma) with healthy human males and females; reports neural activity changes across whole-brain regions (striatum, amygdala, hippocampus, insula, etc.). No indication of psychiatric/neurological patient sample or ROI-only results. Fits inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study of cross-modal person recognition (socially relevant task) in humans. Abstract does not specify participant ages or that analyses were ROI-only, nor does it indicate clinical samples. Key inclusion details (age range, whole-brain vs ROI) are missing, so include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

Study reports fMRI results from patients with schizophrenia as well as healthy volunteers. Exclusion criterion: studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders. Therefore excluded based on abstract.

Abstract states they 'selected brain regions ... as regions of interest' and used seed-based (ROI) functional connectivity analyses; this meets exclusion criterion for ROI analyses. Additionally, the paradigm was resting-state (not an explicit in-scanner social task).

This is a meta-analysis of fMRI studies in schizophrenia patients (clinical population) rather than primary data in healthy adults. It is a meta-analysis/systematic review and reports on participants with a psychiatric disorder, meeting two exclusion criteria.
This article is a systematic review and meta-analysis rather than an original fMRI study of healthy adults; exclusion criterion excludes systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

The study investigates cognitive emotion regulation to positive/negative pictures, not social-related processing. The task and stimuli are emotional but not explicitly social, so it does not meet the review objective of social-processing fMRI studies.

This is a review and meta-analysis (not an original fMRI study) and concerns clinical populations (ASD and schizophrenia). It does not report primary whole-brain fMRI results in healthy adults, meeting exclusion criteria.

Abstract reports results from participants with schizophrenia (clinical population). Exclusion criteria specify excluding studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders. Although healthy controls were included and the task is social and whole-brain, the presence of a psychiatric sample warrants exclusion based on the criteria.

fMRI study where participants processed communicative signals (texts perceived as from friend vs computer) — a social task. Methods use whole-brain MVPA/MVCA (not limited to ROI). Sample appears to be healthy adults; not a review and not clinical. Abstract provides enough evidence to include for full-text extraction (minor uncertainty because age range not explicitly reported).

Study uses resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm and includes participants with schizophrenia (clinical population). This violates inclusion criteria requiring task-based fMRI in healthy adults and exclusion of studies with psychiatric participants. Abstract lacks evidence of relevant whole-brain task results.

Event-related fMRI of emotional infant cries and faces in healthy nulliparous women constituting a social-processing task; whole-brain activations reported across multiple regions. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participants meet 18–60 and health criteria.

Study used resting-state fMRI and coactivation-based parcellation rather than an fMRI task of social processing. Although authors report subregions linked to social cognition, no social-related task during scanning is described in the abstract, so it does not meet the inclusion criterion of an fMRI scan while participants completed a social task.

This paper is a meta-analysis of fMRI studies of psychopathy (a psychiatric disorder), not an original fMRI study in healthy adults performing a social task. It meets exclusion criteria for being a meta-analysis and for reporting results in a clinical (psychopathic) population.

Study used MEG (magnetoencephalography), not functional MRI. Although it studies social (false belief) processing in healthy adults, the imaging modality does not meet the fMRI-only inclusion criterion.

Abstract reports participants with amnestic mild cognitive impairment (aMCI), a neurological disorder and not healthy adults; inclusion criteria require healthy participants aged 18–60. Presence of clinical sample clearly meets an exclusion criterion.

Addresses social processing (theory-of-mind) using fMRI in human participants and reports neural activity in ToM-related regions. Abstract does not state participants’ ages but implies healthy adults and does not clearly report whether results are whole-brain versus ROI-only (mentions independently localized ToM regions), so inclusion is uncertain and warrants full-text review.

Study examines co-occurrence of autism spectrum disorder and ADHD (clinical neurodevelopmental disorders). Participants are not healthy adults, which violates inclusion criteria; exclusion is clear based on abstract.
Study used resting-state fMRI (not a social task) and enrolled participants with autism spectrum disorder (psychiatric condition), not healthy adults. These clearly violate inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports results from participants with autism spectrum disorder (ASD). The exclusion criteria disallow studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric/neurological disorders. Although task is social (fearful face processing), presence of ASD group requires exclusion.

Abstract reports results from patients with schizophrenia (22) in addition to controls. Exclusion criterion disallows studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders; thus excluded despite presence of healthy controls and whole-brain analyses.

fMRI study manipulating self-referential processing and perspective taking during task; reports activations across medial prefrontal cortex (whole-brain activations rather than ROI). Participants appear to be healthy adults (no clinical population mentioned). Age range not specified in abstract — include for full-text review to confirm ages and whole-brain methods.

This study does not report task-based fMRI during a social-related task; it uses resting-state connectivity, meta-analytic connectivity modeling, and structural covariance rather than an experimental social task. Thus it fails the inclusion criterion requiring a functional MRI scan while participants completed a social-related task.

Study participants have autism spectrum disorder (a psychiatric clinical population), not healthy adults; the study focuses on clinical severity and sensory-cognitive network integration rather than fMRI during a social-related task in healthy adults. Therefore it meets exclusion criteria.

Study includes participants with autism spectrum disorder (a psychiatric/neurological disorder). Exclusion criteria disallow studies reporting results among such participants; presence of an ASD group renders the study ineligible despite inclusion of healthy controls.

Abstract reports fMRI hyperscanning during a social joint-attention task, meeting the review objective. However, it does not specify participant health status/ages or whether results are whole-brain versus ROI-only. Insufficient detail to exclude, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Study includes participants with schizophrenia (psychiatric disorder). Exclusion criteria disallow studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders, so exclude despite inclusion of healthy controls and relevant fMRI social task.

Participants are individuals at ultra-high risk for psychosis (a clinical population), not healthy adults aged 18–60. This violates the inclusion criterion of healthy participants; exclusion is clear despite the task being social-related.
Participants are Tourette's syndrome patients (a psychiatric/neurological disorder), not healthy adults; therefore study does not meet the criterion of healthy participants and should be excluded.

Participants fall outside the required age range: the study includes older adults aged 65–75 and younger participants including age 17, whereas the inclusion criterion requires healthy participants aged 18–60. Thus the study does not meet the age eligibility.

Study includes participants with schizophrenia (clinical population) rather than only healthy adults, and the fMRI was resting-state (no social-related task). Focus is on patient vs control differences in reading/auditory processing, so it does not meet the requirement for task-based social processing in healthy adults.

Participants are children and adolescents with autism spectrum disorder (clinical population), not healthy adults aged 18–60. Study therefore does not meet population criteria; also focuses on connectivity rather than task-based fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

Abstract reports relating SRS-A scores to functional connectivity of the pregenual anterior cingulate cortex in neurotypical adults, with no mention of an fMRI social task. This appears to be a seed-based (ROI) connectivity analysis, which meets the exclusion criterion for ROI analyses and does not satisfy the task-based inclusion criterion.

Abstract reports participants with high-functioning autism/Asperger Syndrome (clinical population) and states they used ROI analyses. These violate inclusion criteria (healthy adults only and whole-brain results required).

Study addresses oxytocin effects on processing of socially relevant cues (matches review topic), but the abstract does not specify fMRI methods, participant health status (healthy adults), or whether whole-brain results vs ROI were reported. Insufficient information to rule out exclusion—include for full-text review.

Participants are individuals clinically at risk for psychosis (not healthy adults). This violates the inclusion criterion of healthy participants; exclusion criterion for studies with psychiatric/neurological participants is met.

This study used resting-state fMRI (no social-related task) and reports results from patients with schizophrenia and major depression (with controls). It therefore does not meet the inclusion criterion of task-based social processing in healthy adults and meets the exclusion criterion of reporting patient groups.

Not a task-based social fMRI study: uses resting-state fMRI. Sample includes antipsychotic-naive adolescents with early-onset schizophrenia (clinical population) and healthy adolescents—does not study healthy adults performing a social task.

Includes participants diagnosed with major depressive disorder (psychiatric patients). Presence of a clinical group meets exclusion criterion 'participants with psychiatric disorders', so exclude despite social fMRI task.

Study examines pediatric (adolescent) participants with social anxiety disorder rather than healthy adults 18–60. This is a clinical, pediatric sample, which violates inclusion criteria (healthy adults age 18–60; excludes psychiatric populations).

Abstract implies neural mechanisms of oxytocin but does not specify use of fMRI, participant ages/health, or whole-brain analyses. Insufficient information in abstract to determine inclusion; include for full-text review to confirm fMRI task, healthy adult sample (18–60), and whole-brain results.

Task is a verbal short-term memory (phonological) span task using letters and fingerspelling, not a social-related task. Although fMRI in healthy bilingual adults likely, the study does not investigate social processing, so it does not meet the review objective.

Abstract reports fMRI in a non-clinical (healthy) cohort performing the Reading the Mind in the Eyes Test (a social/ToM task) and describes widespread activity versus a control task, implying whole-brain analysis. However, participant ages are not reported and whole-brain analysis is not explicitly stated. Insufficient detail to confirm age range and analytic scope—include for full-text review to verify eligibility.

Study uses resting-state fMRI (fALFF), not a task-based social processing paradigm, and includes schizophrenia patients. Therefore it does not meet inclusion (task-based social fMRI in healthy adults) and meets exclusion (psychiatric participants) criteria.

Participants are adolescents with autism spectrum disorder (clinical population), not healthy adults aged 18–60. Study used resting-state fMRI and diffusion imaging rather than a task-based social-processing fMRI. Does not meet healthy adult or task-based inclusion criteria.

Study uses resting-state fMRI in adolescents with autism (clinical population), not task-based social processing in healthy adults aged 18–60. Meets exclusion criteria for psychiatric/neurological disorder sample and not a social-task fMRI study.

Abstract reports fMRI studies comparing responses to famous people and social/conceptual words (social concept processing) in presumably healthy adults. The abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state whole-brain vs ROI-only analyses. Insufficient detail to confirm age range and whole-brain results, so include for full-text review to verify eligibility.

Participants are individuals with autism spectrum disorder (clinical population), not healthy adults; task is a precision visuomotor sensorimotor task, not social-related processing. Fails inclusion criteria.

Study used fMRI during a theory-of-mind (social) task in 109 healthy volunteers and reports whole-brain corrected activation results. Age range of participants (18–60) is not specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm the age criterion.

fMRI study of perspective-taking (social cognition) in what appears to be healthy adults; reports engagement of frontoparietal brain regions (whole-brain findings suggested). No ROI-only analysis or clinical population noted. Full text needed to confirm participant ages and whole-brain methods.

The study investigates emotional processing in individuals with Huntington’s disease (a neurological disorder), not healthy adults. Inclusion requires healthy participants aged 18–60; this population violates the exclusion criterion for neurological disorders, so exclude.

Study used resting-state fMRI (no social task) and employed a targeted region-to-region (amygdala–mPFC) analysis — conflicts with inclusion criteria requiring task-based social processing and excluding ROI analyses.

Healthy adult samples (mean ages 22 and 26) with BOLD and structural data related to face-processing reported. The abstract does not state fMRI was acquired during a social-related task nor whether analyses were whole-brain versus ROI. Insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study where healthy adult participants (n=20) performed social-related tasks (observation and imitation of communicative gestures). Abstract reports whole-brain activations (MNS and MS regions) rather than ROI-only analyses and does not indicate clinical populations. Meets inclusion criteria.

Resting-state fMRI in children/adolescents (ages 8–15), not a task-based social processing study; includes participants with autism spectrum disorder (clinical group); participants are not healthy adults aged 18–60. These clearly meet exclusion criteria.

Study includes participants with autism spectrum disorder (a psychiatric/clinical group) and compares them to typically developing boys (minors), so participants are not healthy adults aged 18–60. Therefore it fails the inclusion criteria (healthy adults) and meets the exclusion criterion of reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders.
Study used resting-state fMRI (not a task-based social processing task) and included youth with autism (clinical population), not healthy adults 18-60; therefore does not meet inclusion criteria.

This article is a review summarizing brain-imaging studies (systematic/narrative review), not an original fMRI experiment. It does not report primary fMRI results of social tasks in healthy adults or whole-brain data; therefore it meets the exclusion criterion for reviews.

Abstract does not state whether an fMRI was used or whether whole-brain results are reported. Participants appear to be a general sample (likely healthy) but ages not specified. Insufficient information to confirm fMRI and whole-brain analyses — include for full-text review.

Study investigates borderline personality disorder participants (a psychiatric disorder). Exclusion criterion: studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders — thus excluded despite likely fMRI social task.

The study includes and reports results from participants with autism spectrum disorder (a psychiatric condition). The exclusion criteria state studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders should be excluded. Although it includes typically developing controls and whole-brain fMRI, the presence of ASD clinical participants warrants exclusion.

Study involves participants with autism spectrum disorder and uses resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm; participants are not healthy adults performing a social task, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.
